div.l: ¶ Incipit tractatus Galfri Chaucer de Gestis Peregrinorum versus Cantuariam
Whan that Auerell wtith his shoures soote
The droght of Marche hath ꝑperced to the roote
And bathed euꝰery veyne in swych licour
Of whiche vꝰertu . engendrid is the flour
Whan zephirus eek . wtith his swete breeth
Enspired hath in euꝰery holt and heth
The tendre Croppes . and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram . his half cours y ronne
And smale fowels / maken melodie
That slepen all the nyght with open eye
So priketh hem nature / in her corages
Than longen folke to goon on pilgrymages
And palmers for to seken straunge strondes
To ferne halwes couthe in sondry londes
And specially from euꝰery shires ende
Of Engelond to Caunterbury they wende
The holy blysfull martir forto seke
That hem hath holpen . when that they were seke
Bifell that in that sesoun . on a day
In Southwerk / at the Tabard as I lay
Redy to wenden on my pilgrymage
To Caunterbury . with wel deuout Corage
At nyght was come in to that hostelrie
Wel . xxix . in a compaignye
Of sondry folk / by auenture y falle
In felaueshipe . and pilgrymes were they alle
That toward Caunterbury wolden ryde
The Chambres ⁊ the stables weren wide
And well we weren eesed at the beste
And shortly . whanne the sonne was to reste
So hadde I spoken with hem euꝰerychon
That I was of hir felawship anon
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take oure wey ther as I yow deuyse
But nartheles while I haue tyme ⁊ space
Er that I ferther in this tale pace
Me theyncketh it accordaunt to resoun
To telle yow alle the condicioun
Of eiche of hem . so as it semed mee
And whiche they were ⁊ of what degree
And eek in what array that they were ynne
And at a knyght than will I first begynne
A knyght ther was . ⁊ that a worthy man
That fro the tyme that he first began
To ryden oute he loued cheualrie
Treuthe and honour fredom ⁊ curteisie
Full worthi was he in his lordis werre
And ther to hadde he riden noman ferre
As well in Cristendom as hethenesse
At Alisaundre he was whan it was wonne
And euꝰer honoured for his worthynesse
Full ofte tyme he had the bord bygonne
A boue all nacions in pruce
In lettow had he reised and in Ruce
No Cristen man so ofte of his degree
In Gernade at the sege eke had he bee
At Algezir and riden in Belmarie
At lieis was he / and at Satalye
Whan they were wonne . and in the grete see
At many a noble armee had he bee
At mortell batailles hadde he ben Fyftene
And foughten for oure feith / at Tramyssene
In lystes thries / and ay slayn his foo
This ilke worthy knyght had ben also
Som tyme with the lord of palatye
A gayn a nother hethen in Turkye
And euꝰer more he had a souꝰereyn pris
And thow that he were worthy he was wys
And of his port as meke as is a mayde
Ne neuere yet no vylenye he sayde
In alle his lyfe vnto no maner wight
He was a verrey ꝑperfit gentel knyght
His hors was good but he ne was not gay
But for to tellen yow of his array
Of Fustyan he wered a Gypou
Al bysmotred with his hawbergeou
For he was late comen from his viage
And wente for to do his pilgrymage
With hym ther was his sone a yong squyer
A louer and a lusty bacheler
With lokkes crulle . as they were leyd in presse
Of . xx . yeer he was of age I gesse
Of his stature he was of euene lengthe
And wonderly delyuere . and of grete strengthe
And he had ben sontyme / in chyuachye
In Flaundrys / in Artoys / And Pykardye
And born hym wele as in so litell space
In hope to stonden in his ladies grace
Enbrouded was he / as it were a mede
All full of freisshe floures white and reede
Syngyng he was . or Floytyng alle the day
He was as freisshe / as is the monthe of May
Short was his gowne / with sleues longe ⁊ wyde
Wele coude he sitte on hors and faire ride
He coude songes well make / and endite
Iuste and eke daunce / and well purtreye ⁊ write
So hote he louede / that by nyghter tale
He slepte namore / than dooth a nyghtyngale
Curteys he was . lowely . and seruysable
And carf byforn his Fader at the table
A yeman had he / and serauntz namo
At that tyme / for hym lyst ryde so
And he was clad / in cote ⁊ hode of grene
A sheef of Pecok arwes . bright ⁊ kene
Vnder his belte he bare full thriftely
Wele coude he dresse his takel yemanly
His arwes drouped nought with fetheres lowe
And in his hond he bare a myghty bowe
A nott heed had he / with a broun visage
Of wodecraft wel koude he / alle the vsage
Vpon his arme he bare a gay bracer
And by his syde a swerd and a bokeler
And on that oother syde / a gay daggere
Harneysed wel . and sharp as poynt of spere
A xpofre on his breest of siluer shene
An horn he bare / the bawdryk / was of grene
A Forster was he / soothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a Prioresse
That of her smylyng was full symple ⁊ coy
Hir grettest ooth / was but by seynt loy
And she was cleped Madame Eglyntyne
Full well she songe the seruyse dyuyne
Entuned in her nose / full semely
And Frensshe she spak full faire ⁊ fetisly
After the scole of Stratford atte bowe
For Frensshe of Parys was to hir vnknowe
Atte mete wele taught was she wtith alle
She leet no morsell from her lippes falle
Ne wette her fyngeres / in her sauce depe
Wele coude she carie a morsell ⁊ wele kepe
That no drope fel vpon her breest
In curtesie was set full mochel her leest
Her ouer lippe wiped she so clene
That in here cuppe / ther was no ferthyng sene
Of grees whan she dronken had hir draught
Full semely aftir her mete she raught
And sykerly she was of greet disport
And full plesaunt and amyable of port
And peyned hire to countrefete chere
Of court . And estatlyche of manere
And to ben holden digne of reuerence
But for to speken of hire conscience
She was so charitable ⁊ so pitous
She wolde wepe / if that she saugh a Mows
Caught in a trappe / if it were ded or bledde
Of smale houndes had she that she fedde
With rosted fleisshe or melke or wastel breed
But soore wepte she / if oon of hem were deed
Or if men smote it with a yerd smerte
And all was conscience and tendre herte
Full symely her wympel pynched was
Hire nose streight hire eyen grey as glas
Hire mouthe full smal / and therto softe ⁊ reed
But sikerly she hadde a faire forheed
It was almost a spanne brood I trowe
For hardely she was not vnder growe
Full fetys was hire cloke as I was ware
Of small corall a boute hire arm she bare
A peyre of bedys / gauded al with grene
And ther on henge a broche of gold full shene
On whiche was first writen a crowned A .
And aftir . Amor vincit omia .
A nother nonne with hire had she
That was hire chapeleyn . and preestes thre
A Monke ther was a faire for the maistrie
An out ridere that loued venerie
A manly man to been an Abbot Able
Full many a deynte hors hadde he in stable
And when he rood men myght his bridell here
Gyngle in a whystelyng wynd as clere
And eke as loude / as doth the chapell belle
There as this lord was kepere of the Selle
The reule of seynt Maure or of seynt Benett
By cause that it was olde ⁊ somdell streit
This ilke monke leet olde thynges pace
And helde aftir the newe world the space
He yaf not of that text a pulled hen
That seith that hunters ben noon holy men
Ne that a Monke whan that he is reccheles
Ys lykkened till a Fissh that is waterles
This is to seyn / a Monke out of his Cloystre
But thilke tixte held he not worth an oystre
And I saide his opynyoūn was good
What sholde he studie . ⁊ make hym seluen wood
Vpon a book / in Cloistre alwey to poure
Or swynk with his hondes ⁊ laboure
As Austyn bit . how shall the world be serued
Lat Austyn to hym haue his swynk reserued
Therfore he was a prikesour a right
Greyhoundes he had as swyft as fowel in flyght
Of Prykyng and of huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for no cost wolde he spare
I saugh his slefes purfiled at the hond
With Grys and that the fynest of a lond
And for to festene his hood vnder his chyn
He had of golde wrought a full curious pyn
A loue knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His heed was balled that shoon as ony glas
And eke his face as he had ben anoynt
He was a lord full fat ⁊ in good poynt
His eyen stepe / and rollyng in his hed
That semed as a furneys of a leed
His botes souple / his hors in greet estat
Now serteinly / he was a feire pꝰerlat
He was not pale . as is a forpyned goost
A fat swan loued he best of any roost
His Palfrey was as broun as any berye
A Frere ther was . a wantou ⁊ a merie
A lymytour . a full solempne man
In all the ordres foure / is non that kan
So myche of daliaunce / and faire langage
He had maked full many amariage
Of yong wymen / at his owne cost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble post
Full well byloued ⁊ famulier was he
With frankeleyns ouꝰeral in his cuntre
And eke with worthy women of the toun
For he had pouer of confessioun
As seide hym self . more than a curat
For of his ordre he was licenciat
Full swetely herd he confessioun
And plesaunt was his Absolucoun
He was an esy man to yeue penance
Ther as he wiste to haue a good pitaraunce
For vn to a pore ordre for to yeue
Is signe that a man is well shryue
For if he yaf he durste make auaunt
He wist that a man was repentaraunt
For many a man so herde is of hert
He may not wepe though that he soore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepyng and preieris
Men mote yeue siluer to the pore freris
His tipet was ay farsed full of knyfes
And pynnes for to yeue faire wyfes
And certeynly he had a mury note
Wele coude he syngen and pleyen at a Rote
Of yeddynges he bare outerly the prys
His nekke white was as the floure delys
Therto he stronge was as a champioun
He knew the tauernes well in euꝰery toun
And euꝰery hostiler ⁊ tappestere
Bet than a lazar or a beggere
For vn to swiche a worthy man as hee
Accorded nat as by his facultee
To haue with sike lazers Acqueyntaraunce
Yt is not honest it may not avaunce
For to delyn with no such poraille
But all with riche and sellers of vitaille
And ouꝰer all ther as ꝓprofit sholde arise
Corteys he was ⁊ lowely of seruyse
Ther was noman nowher so vertuous
He was the beste begger of his hous
And yaf a certeyn ferme for the garaunt
Noon of his bretheren coom in his haunt
For thogh a widwe had not a shoo
So plesaunt was his In Principio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthyng er he went
His purchas was well bettre than his rent
And rage he coude as it were right a whelp
In louedaies koude he mochell help
For ther he was not lyke a Cloystrer
With a thredbare cope as is a poore scoler
But he was lyke a maister / or a pope
Of double worsted was his semy cope
And rounded as a belle out of the presse
Somwhat he lypsed for his wantownesse
To make his englysshe swete vpon his tonge
And in his harpyng whan he hadde songe
Hise eyen twynkeled in his heed aright
As doon the sterres in the frosty nyght
This worthy lymytour was cleped huberd
A Marchaunt was ther / with a forked berd
In motlee / and heigh on hors he sat
Vpon his heed a Flaundrissh beuer hat
His bootes clapsed / faire and fetisly
Hise resouns he spak full solempnely
Sownyng alwey thencres of his wynnyng
He wold the see were kept for any thyng
Bitwix Middelburgh and Orewelle
Wele koude in eschaunge / sheldes selle
This worthy man full well his wit bysette
Ther wist no wyght that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his gouꝰernaunce
With his bergeynes / and with his cheuysaunce
Forsoth he was a worthy man with alle
But sooth to seyn I note how men hym calle
A Clerk ther was of Oxenford alsoo
That vnto logyk hadde longe y goo
As lene was his hors / as is a rake
And he was not right fat I vndertake
But loked holwe and therto sobrely
Full threedbare was his ouerist courtepy
For he had geten hym / yet no benefice
Ne was so wordly for to haue office
For hym was leuere / haue at his beddes heed
Twenty bokes / clad in blak or reed
Of Aristotell / and his philosophie
Than robes riche / or fithle / or gay sawtrie
But all be that he was a philosophre
Yet hadde he / but litel gold in Coffre
But all that he myght of his frendes hente
On bokes and on lernyng he it spente
And bysely gan for the soules preye
Of hem that yaf hym wherwith to scoleye
Of stodie toke he moost cure / and moost hede
Nat a word spake he / more than was nede
And that was seide / in fourme and reuerence
And short and quyk and full of high sentence
Sownyng in morall sentence vꝰertu was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne / and gladly teche
A sergeaunt of the lawe war and wys
That often hadde ben at the parvys
That was also full riche of excellence
Discret he was / and grete reuerence
He semed swiche / hise wordes weren so wise
Iustice he was full often in assise
By patent and by pleyn cōmmyssioun
For his science / and for his high renoun
Of fees and robes hadde he many oon
So greet a purchasour was nowher noon
Al was fee simple to hym in effecte
His parachasyng myght noght ben infecte
Nowhere so besy a man / as he ther nas
And semed besier than he was
In termes hadde he caas ⁊ domes alle
That from the tyme of kyng william were falle
Therto he coude endite / and make a thyng
Ther koude no wight pynche at his wrytyng
And euꝰery statut koude he playn by rote
He rood but hoomly / in a medlee cote
Girt with a seint of silke / wtith barres smale
Of his array telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in his companye
Whit was his berd / as is the daiesye
Of his complexion / he was sangwyn
Wele loued he by the morwe / a soppe in wyn
To lyuen in delyt was euꝰer his wone
For he was Epicurus owne sone
That helde opynyon / that pleyn delyt
Was verrey felicitee ꝑperfit
An housholdere / ⁊ that a greet was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his Cuntre
His breed / ⁊ Ale / was alweys aftir oon
A bettre envyned man / was neuꝰer noon
With outen bake mete was neuꝰer his hous
Of fisshe and fleissh / and that so plentevous
It snewed in his hous / of mete ⁊ of drynke
Of alle deyntees / that men couthe bythynke
Aftyr the sondry sesons / of the yeer
So chaunged he his mete / and his soper
Full many a fat partriche / hadde he in mewe
And many a breem / and many a luce in stue
Woo was his Cook but if his sauce were
Poynaunt and sharp / and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle alway
Stood redy couꝰered all the longe day
At Sessions ther was he lord and sire
Full ofte tyme he was knyght of the shire
An Anlas and a Gipser all of selke
Heng at his gurdell white as morn melke
A shirreue had he ben / and countour
Was nowher suche a worthy vauasour
An habirdaisshere / and a Carpentere
A webbe / a dyer / a Tapicer
And they were clothed all in o lyuere
Of a solempne / and a grete fraternyte
Full freisshe and newe / hire geere a piked was
Hire knyfes were chaped / noght with bras
But all with siluer / wroght / full clene ⁊ wele
Hire girdles and hire pouches eueridele
Wele semed eche of hem / a faire burgeys
To sitten in a yeldhalle on a deys
Euꝰerych for the wisdom that he kan
Was shaply for to ben an Alderman
For catell had thay I nough and rente
And eeke hire wifes / wold it wele assente
Or elles serteyn / they were to blame
It is full faire to be clepid madame
And goon to vigiles al byfore
And haue a mantell realliche y bore
A Cook thay hadde with hem for the nones
To boille the Chiknes And the Maribones
And poudre Marchaunt tart ⁊ galyngale
Wele koude he knowe / a draught of londou ale
He koude rooste and sethe / and broille and frie
Maken Mortreux . and wel bake a pie
But greet harm was it . as it thoughte me
That on his shyne / a mormall hadde he
For blak manger / that made he with the beste
A shipman was there wonyng fer by weste
For ought I woot he was of Dertemouthee
He rood vpon a rouncy as he couthee
In a gowne of Faldyng to the knee
A dagger on a lace hongyng had hee
A boute his nekke / vnder his arme a doun
The hote somer / hadde made his hewe all broun
And certeynly he was a good felawe
Full many a draught of wyn hadde he drawe
Fro Burdeux warde / whill that the chapman sleep
Of nyce conscience toke he no keep
If that he faught and hadde the hier hond
By watre he sente hem hoom / to euꝰery lond
But of his crafte to rekene wele his tydes
Hys stremys and his daungers / hym bysydes
His herberwe / and his moone / his lodemenage
Ther was noon suche / fro hulle to cartage
Hardy he was / and wys to vndirtake
With many a tempest hadde his berde ben shake
He knewe alle the hauenes as they were
Froo Scōmotlond to the Cape of Fynystere
And euꝰery Crike in Britaigne and in Spayne
His barge I cleped was the Mawdelayne
With vs ther was a doctour of Phisike
In all this world ne was ther noon hym lyke
To speken of Phisyk and of Surgerie
For he was grounded / in Astronomye
He kepte his pacient a full greet deel
In houres by his magik naturell
Wele koude he fortunen / the Ascendent
Of hise ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of euꝰery maladye
Were it of hoot or coold or moyst or drye
And where it engendrid and of what humour
He was a verray practisour
The cause y knowe / and of his harme the roote
Anoon he yaf the syke man his bote
Full redy had he hise Apothecaries
To senden hym his dregges and letuaries
For eche of hem made other for to wynne
Hire frendship was nought newe for to begynne
Well knewe he / the olde Esculapius
And discorides / and eke Rusus
Olde ypocras / haly and Galien
Serapion Razis / and Auycen
Averrois Damascien and Constantyn /
Bernard and Gatesden / and Gilbertyn
Of his diete mesurable was hee
For it was of noo suꝑperfluytee
But of grete norissynge / and digestible
His studie was but litle on the bible
In sangwyn and in Pers he clad was al
Lyned with taffata and with sendal
And yet he was but easy of dispense
He kepte that he wan in pestilence
For gold in Phisik is a cordiall
Therfore he loued gold in speciall
A good wife was ther of bysyde bathe
But she was somdel deef and that was scathe
Of clooth makyng she hadde suche an haunt
She passed hem of Ipres and of Gaunt
In all the parisshe wife ne was ther noon
That to the offryng byfore here sholde goon
And if ther didde certein so wroth was she
That she was oute of alle charite
Hire keuerches full fyn were of ground
I durste swere they weyeden ten pound
That on a sonday weren on her hed
Hire hosen were of fyne scarlet reed
Full streite y teyd / and shoes full moist ⁊ newe
Bolde was her face / and faire and reed of hewe
She was a worthy woman all here lyue
Housbandes at chirche dore / she hadde fyue
With outen other compaignye in youthe
But ther of nedeth nat to speke as nouthe
And thries had / she ben at Ierusalem
She hadde passed many a stronge streem
At Rome she hadde ben / and at Boloyne
In Galys at seynt Iame / and at Coloyne
She koude moche of wandryng by the weye
Gattothed was she / sootly for to seye
Vpon an amblere / esily she sat
Wympled wel / and on here hede an hat
As brood as is a bokeler . or a targe
A foot mantel a boute here hipes large
And on here feet apeire of spores sharpe
In felaushipe / wele couthe she laugh ⁊ karpe
Of remedies of loue she knewe ꝑperchaunce
For she couthe of that arte the olde daunce
A good man was there of religioun
And was a pore ꝑperson of a toun
But riche he was of holy thought ⁊ werke
He was also a lerned man a Clerke
That Cristes gospell treuly wolde preche
Hise parisshens / deuoutly wolde he teche
Benigne he was / and wonder diligent
And in aduꝰersite full pacient
And swiche he was preued ofte sithes
Full looth were hym to cursen for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeuen oute of doute
Vn to his poore parisshens aboute
Of his offrynge / and eke of his substaunce
He couthe in litel thyng haue suffissaunce
Wide was his parisshe / and houses fer asonder
But he ne lefte nat / for reyne ne thonder
In sikenesse nor in meschef to visite
The ferrest in his parisshe / moche ⁊ lite
Vpon his feet . and in his hoond a staf
This noble ensample to his sheep he yaf
That first he wroughte / ⁊ aftirward / that he taught
Oute of the gospel he tho wordes caught
And thys figure he added eke therto
That if golde ruste what / what sholde yren do
For if a preost be foule in whom we truste
No wonder is a lewed man to ruste
And shame it is if a preest take kepe
An shiten shipherd / and a clene shepe
Wele ought a preest ensample for to yeve
To hys spee parchons how they shold lyve
He sette nought his benefice to hire
And leet his sheep encombred in the myre
And ranne to loundoūn / vnto seint poules
To seken hym a Chauntrie for soules
Or with a bretherhede to ben witholde
But dwelte at hoom ⁊ kepte wele his foolde
So that the wolfe made it not myscarie
He was a sheephurd / and nat a mercenarie
And though he holy were and vertuouse
He was not to synfull men dispetouse
Ne of of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his techyng discreet and benygne
To drawen folke to heuen / by faiernesse
By good ensample / this was his besynesse
But it were any ꝑpersone obstynat
What so he were of high or lowe estat
Hym wolde he snybben / sharply for the nonys
A better preest I trowe ther nowher noon is
He wayted / aftir noo pompe ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience
But cristes lore / and hise apostles twelue
He taughte / but first he folwed it hym selue
With hym ther was a plowman . was his brother
That had y ladde of donge full many a fother
A trewe swynkere / and a good was he
Lyuyng in pees / and ꝑperfit charite
God loued he best with all his hole herte
Atte alle tymes / though hym gamed or smerte
And than his neighebore / right as hym selue
He wolde thresshe / and therto dyke and delue
For cristis sake for euꝰery pore wight
With outen hire if it lay in his myght
His tithes paide he full faire ⁊ well
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke / and his catell
In his tabard he rood vpon a Mere
Ther was also a Reeue and a Millere
A sompnour and a pardoner also
A Manciple and my selfe ther were namo
The Millere was a stoute karl for the nones
Full bigg he was of braun ⁊ eke of bones
That preued wele / for ouꝰer all ther he cam
At wrastlyng he wolde haue alway the Ram
He was short sholdred brood a thikke knarre
Ther was no dore that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his heed
His berde as any sowe / or fox was reed
And therto brood as though it were a spaade
Vpon the coppe right of his nose he hade
A wert . and ther on stood a tofte of heris
Reed as the brustles of a sowe eeris
Hise nosethirles blake were ⁊ wide
A swerde and a bokeler bare he be his side
His Mouthe as grete was / as a greet furneys
He was a Ianglere / and a Goliardeis
And that was moste of synne / and harlotries
Wele couthe he stelen corn / and tollen thries
And yet he hadde a thombe of golde ꝑperdee
A white cote and a blewe hood wered he
A bagge pipe wele coude he blowe and sowne
And therwith al / he brought vs oute of towne
A gentell Maunciple was ther of a temple
Of whiche all chatours myght take exemple
For to ben wise in bying of vitaille
For whether that he paide or toke by taille
Algat he waited so in his achate
That he was ay byforn and in good state
Now is not that of god a full faire grace
That swiche a lewed mannys witte shall pace
The wisdom of an heep / of lerned men
Of Maistres hadde he moo / than twies ten
That were of lawe exꝑpert and curious
Of whiche ther were a duzeyn in that hous
Worthy to ben stiwardes / of rent and lond
Of any lord that is in Engelond
To make hym lyue by his ꝓpropre good
In honour dettelees / but he were wood
Or lyve as scarsly / as hym lyst desire
And able for to helpen all a shire
In any caas / that myghte falle or happe
And yet this Maunciple / sette her aller cappe
The Reue was a sklender Coleryk man
His berde was shaue / as neigh as euꝰer he kan
His heer was by hise erys full rounde y shorn
His topp was dokked lyke a preest byforn
Full longe were his legges / and full lene
I lyke a staf ther was no calfe y sene
Wele couthe he kepe / a gerner and a bynne
Ther was noon Auditour / koude on hym wynne
Wele wiste he by the droughte / And by the Reyn
The yeldyng of his seed and of his greyn
His lordeshep / his neet / his deyerie
His swyn his hors / his stoor / and his pultrie
Was holly in this Reues gouernyng
And by his couenant / yaf the rekenyng
Syn that his lord was twenty yere of age
There coude noman brynge hym in arerage
Ther nas baillif ne herde / nor other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleighte / ⁊ his couyne
They were a dradde of hym / as of the deth
His wonyng was full faire / vpon an heth
With grene trees shadwed was his place
He koude bettre than his lord purchace
Full Riche he was a stored priuely
His lorde wele koude he pleasen subtilly
To yeue and lene hym of his owne good
And haue a thank and yet a coot and a hood
In youthe he lerned hadde / a good myster
He was a well good wright a Carpenter
This Reue satte vpon a wele good stot
A longe Surcote of peers vpon he hadde
And by his side he bare a rusty blade
Of Northfolke was this Reeue / of whiche I telle
Byside a toun men clepe Baldeswelle
Tukked he was / as is a frere a boute
And euꝰer he rood the hyndrest of oure route
A Sompnour was there with vs in that place
That hadde a fire reed Cherubyns face
For Saucefleme / he was with eyen narwe
And hoot he was / and lecherous as a sparwe
With scaled browes blake / and piled berd
Of his visage children weren a ferd
Ther nas quik siluer / litarge ne brymston
Borace ceruce ne oile of tartre noon
Ne oygnement that wolde clense and bite
That hym myght helpen of hise welkes white
Ne of the knobbes sittyng on his chekys
Wele loued he garlek onyons ⁊ eke lekes
And for to drynken strong wyn reed as blood
Than wolde he and crie as he were wood
Than wolde he speke no word but in latyne
That he had lerned out of som decree by tyme
No wonder is / he hard it all the day
And eeke ye knowen wele how that a Iay
Kan clepen watte / as wele as kan the pope
But who so koude in other thyng hym grope
Than had he spent all his Philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wold he crie
He was a gentell harlot and a kynde
A bettre felawe / sholde men nought fynde
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyn
A good felawe to haue his concubyn
A twelfe monthe / and excusen hym atte fulle
Full priuely a fynche eke coude he pulle
And if he foond o where a good felawe
He wolde techen hym to haue noon awe
In suche caas / as the Ercedeknes curs
But if mannes soule / were in his purs
For in his purs he sholde punysshed be
Purs is the Ercedeknes helle seide he
But wele I woot he lied right in dede
Of cursyng ought iche gilti man drede
For curs wole slee / right as a soillyng sauyth
And also ware hym of a Significauit
In daunger hadde he atte his owne gyse
The yonge gerles / of the diocise
And knewe her counseill / and was all hire reed
A garland hadde he set vpon his heed
As grete as it were for ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made hym of a Cake
With hym ther rood a gentell pardoner
Of Rouncyual his frende and his comper
That streight was comen from the court of Rome
Full loude he songe come hedir loue to me
This sompnour bare to hym a styf burdoun
Was neuer trompe . of halfe so greet a soun
This pardoner had heer as yelowe as wexe
And smothe it henge as doth a strike of flexe
By ounces henge his lokkes that he hadde
And ther with he his sholdres ouꝰer spradde
But thynne it lay by colpons oon and oon
But hood for Iolite wered he noon
For it was trussed vp in his walet
Hym thought he rood all of the newe gett
Discheuelee saue his cappe he rood all bare
Swiche glaryng eyen hadde he as an hare
A vernycle had hee sowed vpon his cappe
His walet byforn hym in his lappe
Bret full of pardoun / comen from Roome all hoot
A voys he hadde as smalle as hath a goot
No berde hadde he / ne neuꝰer sholde haue
As smothe it was / as it were late y shaue
I trowe he were a geldyng or a Mare
But of his crafte fro Berwik in to ware
Ne was there suche a nother ꝑperdonere
For in his male / he hadde a pilwe bere
Whiche that he saide / was oure lady veile
He seide he hadde a gobet of a seile
That seint petir hadde / whan that he wente
Vpon the see til Ihu crist hym hente
He hadde a crosse of latoun full of stones
And in a glasse he hadde pigges bones
But with these relykes / whan that he fond
A pore parson dwellyng vpon lond
Vpon a day he gate hym more moneye
Than that the ꝑpersoun gate in Monthes tweye
And thus with feyned flaterie and Iapes
He made the ꝑpersoun and the peple his Apes
But treuly to tellen atte laste
He was in chirche a noble Ecclesiaste
Wele koude he reede a lessoun ⁊ a storie
But altherbeste he song an offertorie
For well he wist whan that songe was songe
He moste preche / and wele affile his tonge
To wynne siluer / as he full wele koude
Therfore he songe the murierly ⁊ loude
Now haue I told yow sootly in a clause
Thestaat tharray / the nombre and eke the cause
Why that assembled was this compaignye
In Southwerk / in that gentil hostelrie
That hight the Tabard fast by the belle
But now is tyme to yow for to telle
How that we baren / vs that ilke nyght
Whan that we were in that hostelrie a light
And aftyr wole I telle of oure viage
And all the remenant of oure pilgrimage
But now first I pray yow of youre curtesie
That ye narette it not my vilenye
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To telle yow here wordes ⁊ here chere
Ne though I speke her wordes ꝓproprely
For this ye knowen / also wele as I

l.hi: Who so shall telle a tale aftir a man
He moot reherce as euꝰer he kan

div.l: Eueriche a word if it be in his charge

l.hi: All speke he neuꝰer so rudelyche and large
Or ellys moot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thyng or fynde wordys newe
He may not spare all though he were his brother
He moot as wele seye o word as a nother
Crist spake hym selfe full brood in holy writ
And wele ye woot no vileynye is it
Eke Plato seith who so kan hym rede
The wordes mote be Cosyn to the dede

div.l: Also I pray yow to foryeue it mee
All haue I not set folke in here degree
Here in this tale as that they sholde stonde
My witte is short ye may wele vndirstonde
Greet chere made oure hoost vs euerichon
And to the sopere / sette he vs a noon
He serued vs with vitaille at the beste
Stronge was the wyn ⁊ wele to drynke vs leste
A semely man oure hoost was with alle
For to been a Marchal in an halle
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A fairer burgeis is ther noon in chepe
Bolde of his speche / ⁊ wis ⁊ wele y taught
And of manhood hym lakked right naught
Eke therto he was a mury man
And aftir souper / pleynen he bygan
And spake of myrthe / a monges other thynges
Whan that we hadde made oure rekenynges
And seide thus / now lordes treuly
Ye ben to me right welcome hertely
For by my trouthe yf that I shall not lye
I saugh not this yeere so meri a companye
At oones in this herburgh as is now
Fayne wolde I doon yow myrthe wyste I how
And of a myrthe I am right now bythought
To doon yow ease / ⁊ it it shall cost yow nought
Ye goon to Caunterbury ward god yow spede
The blysfull martir quyte yow youre mede
And wele I woot . as ye goon by the wey
Ye shapen yow to talen and to pleye
For treuly comfort ne myrthe is noon
To ride by the wey dombe as a stoon
And therfore wole I maken yow desport
As I saide erst ⁊ do yow som comfort
And if yow liketh all by oon assent
For to stōmden at my Iugement
And for to werken as I yow saye
To Morwe whan ye riden by the waye
Now by my fader soule that is deed
But ye be mury I wole yeve yow myn heed
Holde vp youre hondes with outen Moore speche
Oure counseille was not longe for to seche
Vs thought it was nat worth to make it wyse
And graunted hym with wotyn moore auyse
And bade hym seye this voirdit as hym lyeste
Lordynges qd he / now herkneth for the beste
But taketh it nat I pray yow in desdeyn
This is the poynt to speke short and pleyn
That eche of yow / to short with oure weye
In this viage shall telle tales tweye
To Caunterbury ward I mene it soo
And homward he shall tellen other twoo
Of Auentures that whilom haue byfalle
And whiche of yow that bereth best of alle
That is to seyn / that tellith in this caas
Tales of beste sentence / and most solaas
Shall haue a soper / at oure allere cost
Here in this place / sittyng by this post
Whan that we come agayn to Caunterbury
And for to make yow the more mury
I wol my self goodly with yow ride
Ryght at myn owne cost / and be youre gyde
And who so wole my Iugement with seye
Shall paye all that we spende by the weye
And if that ye vouche sauf that it be soo
Telle me a noon with outen wordes moo
And I wole erly shape me therfore
This thyng was graunted and oure othes swore
With full gladde herte / and preyden hym also
That he wolde fouche sauf forto do so
And that he wolde be oure gouꝰernour
And of oure tales Iugge and reportour
And sette a soper atte a certeyn pris
And we wole reuled ben at his deuys
In high and lough / and thus by oon assent
We ben accorded to his Iugement
And ther vpon the wyn was fet a noon
We dronken and to reste echon
With outen any lenger tarying
A Morwe whan that day bygan to spryng
Vp roos oure oost ⁊ was oure aller cokke
And gadrid vs to gedir in a flokke
And forth we riden a litel moore than pas
Vn to the wateryng of seint Thomas
And there oure hoost bygan his hors areste
And seide lordynges herkeneth if yow leste
Ye woot youre forward / ⁊ it yow recorde
If euesong and morwe song accorde
Lat see now whoo shall telle the first tale
As euꝰer mote I drynke wyn or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iuggement
Shall pay for all that by the wey ys spentby the wey ys spent
Now draweth cutte er that we ferther twynne
He whiche that hath the shortest shall begynne
Sire knyght quod he / my maister and my lord
Now draweth cutte for that is myn accord
Cometh neer quod he my lady prioresse
And ye sire Clerke / late be youre shamefastnesse
Ne studieth nat lay hond to euꝰery man
Anoon to drawen euꝰery wight bygan
And shortly for to tellen as it was
Were it by auenture / or sort / or cas
The soth is this / the cutte fell to the knyght
Of whiche full blithe was euꝰery wight
And telle he moste his tale as was resoun
By forward and by composicioun
As ye han herde what nedeth wordes moo
And whan this good man saugh that it was soo
As he that wyse was / and obedient
To kepe his forward by his free assent
He seide syn I shall bygynne the game
What welcome be the cutte in goddis name
Now late vs ride / and herkeneth what I seye
And whth that word we riden forth oure weye
And he bygan with right amery chere
His tale a noon and seide as ye may here

l.hi: Iamque domos patria scithice post aspera gentis laurigero et cetera

div.l:
(base) Iamque domos patria Stithite post asꝑpera gentis laurigers ⁊c
Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Wilom as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duke that hight Theseus
(base) Of Athenes / he was lorde ⁊ gouernour
(base) And in his tyme swyche a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Full many a Riche cuntree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wisdom / and his chiualrie
(base) He conquered all the reigne of femenye
(base) That whilom was I cleped Scithia
(base) And wedded the queene ypolita
(base) And brought hire hom with hym in his contree
(base) With mychel glorie ad solempnytee
(base) And eeke hire suster Emelie
(base) And thus with victorie ⁊ with melodie
(base) Late I this noble duke to Athenes ride
(base) And alle his hoost in armes hym byside
(base) And certes if it nere to long to here
(base) I wolde haue tolde fully the manere
(base) How wonnen was the reigne of femenye
(base) By theseus . and by his chiualrie
(base) And the grete bataille for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Athenes / ⁊ Amazones
(base) And how asseged was Ipolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste that was at hire weddynge
(base) And of the tempest of her home comynge
(base) But all that thynge I mote as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large felde to ere
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And wayke ben the Oxen in my plow
(base) The remenant of my tale is longe I now
(base) I wolle nat letten eke noon of this route
(base) Late euꝰery felawe telle his tale a boute
(base) And lat see now whoo shall the soper wynne
(base) And there I lefte I wole a yein bygynne
(base) ¶ Incipit / narracio
(base) This duke of whom I make of mencoun
(base) Whan he was comon almoost to the toun
(base) In alle his wele and in his moste pride
(base) He was ware as he caste his eye aside
(base) Where that there kneled in the hie weye
(base) A Compaignye of ladies twey ⁊ tweye
(base) Eche aftir /other cladde in clothes bakeblakeblake
(base) But swiche a crie / and swyche a woo they make
(base) That in this worlde nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herd suche a nother waymentynge
(base) And of this crie . they nolde neuꝰer styntyn
(base) Til they the reynes of his bridell hentyn
(base) What folke be ye / that at myn home comynge
(base) Parturben so my feste / with criynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so grete enuye
(base) Of myn honour that thus compleyne ⁊ crie
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offendid
(base) And tellith me if it may ben amendid
(base) And why that ye ben clothed thus in blak
(base) The oldest lady of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned with a dedly chere
(base) That it was reuthe to seen ⁊ here
(base) She saide lorde to whom fortune hath yeuen
(base) Victorie / and / as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Nat greueth vs / youre glorie and youre honour
(base) But we bysechen mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure woo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentilnesse
(base) Vppon vs wrecched women / late thow falle
(base) For certes lorde / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hathe ben a duchesse or a quene
(base) Now be we caitifes / as it is wele sene
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thanked be fortune and his false whele
(base) That noon estate assureth to be wele
(base) Now certes lorde to abiden youre pꝰersence
(base) Here in this Temple of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue ben waytyng all this fourten nyght
(base) Now helpe vs lord sith it lith in thy myght
(base) I wrecche whiche that wepe ⁊ waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyfe to kyng Canpaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we that ben in this array
(base) And maken all this lamentacoūnn
(base) We losten all oure housbondes at that toun
(base) While that the sege ther a boute lay
(base) And yet now the olde Creon weylaway
(base) That lord is now at Thebes the Cite
(base) Fulfild of Ire and of Iniquite
(base) He for despit. and for his Tirannye
(base) To doon the deed bodies vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that ben slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodies on an hepe I drawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neither to ben I buryed nor I brent
(base) But maketh houndes eten hem in despite
(base) And with that worde with oute more respite
(base) They fillen gruf and criden pitously
(base) Haue on vs wrecched womenne som mercy
(base) And late oure sorwe / synke in thyn herte
(base) This gentil duke / doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thought that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous and so maat
(base) That whilom weren of so greet estaat
(base) And in his armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem comforteth in full good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon so ferfoth his myght
(base) Vpon the Tirant Creon hem to wreke
(base) That alle the puple of grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creon was of Theseus y serued
(base) As he that hadde his deth wele deserued
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And right a noon / with outen moore a bood
(base) His banner he desplaieth and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward and alle his oost biside
(base) No neer Athenes / wolde he goo nene ride
(base) Ne take his eese / fully halfe a day
(base) But outward on his way / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente A noon Ipolita the queene
(base) And Emelie her yonge sister sheene
(base) Vn to the toun of Athenes to dwelle
(base) And forth he ritte ther is nomore to telle
(base) The reed statue of Mars / wtith spere and targe
(base) So shyneth in his white baner large
(base) That alle the feldes glitren vp ⁊ doun
(base) And by his baner. born is his penoun
(base) Of golde full riche / in whiche ther was y bete
(base) The Mynotaur / whiche that he wan in Crete
(base) Thus rit this Duk thus rit this conqueroure
(base) And in oost of Chiualrie the floure
(base) Tyl he cam to Thebes / and a light
(base) Faire in a felde / ther as he thought fight
(base) But shortly for to speken / of thys thyng
(base) With Creon whiche that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slough hym manly as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and put the folke to flyght
(base) And by Assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente a doun / bothe walle ⁊ sparre ⁊ rafter
(base) And to the ladies he restored a gayn
(base) The bones of her freendes / that weren slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gise
(base) But it were alto longe for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentyng
(base) That the ladies made / at the brennyng
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Doth to the ladies / whan they from hym went
(base) But shortly for to telle / is myn entent
(base) Whan that this worthy duk this Theseus

W Whan that the knyght had thus his tale y tolde

div.l: Faire was this yonge wyf and ther with al

Vppon this nombre difinicioun

Why sholde men thanne speke of it vilenye ;
Lo here the wyse kyng Daun Salamon

God woot this noble kyng as to my witte

For ꝑperil is bothe fire and tough tasemble
Ye knowe what this sample may resemble

And euꝰery hath of god a ꝓpropre yefte
Some this som that as hym liketh shefte

And lordynges be youre leue that am nat I

Telle me also what conclusioun
Were membres made of generacioun
And of so ꝑperfit wys a wyght I wrought
Trusteth right wele they were nat made for noght

That they were made for purgacioun

The exꝑperience wote wele it is nat soo

That man shal yelden to his wif his dette

I haue the poere duryng al my lyf
Vpon his ꝓpropre body and not he

Vp stirt the ꝑperdoner and that a noon

Gladly quod she syn it may yow lyke

Yef that I speke aftir my fantasye
As taketh nat a greef of that I seye
For myn entent is but for to pleye
Now sir than wille I telle yow forth my tale

Vnneth myght they the statuyte holde

Ye woot wele what I mene of this parde

How pitously a nyght I made hem swynke
But be me fey I tolde of it noo store

They loued me so wele by god a boue

Hath me byraft my beaute and my pith

The floure is goon ther is nomore to telle

To prechyng eke and to pilgrimages
To pleies of myracle and of mariages
And wered vpon / my gay scarlet gytes /
This wormes ne this moththes ne thys mytes
Vpon my parel fret hem neuꝰer a dele
And woostowe why ; for they were vsed wele /
Now wole I tellen forth what happed me /
I sey that in the feldes walked we
Tyl trewely we hadde suche dalyaunce
This clerke and I that of my purueaunce
I spake to hym and saide hym how that he /
(Yef I were widewe) shulde wedde me
For certeynly I sey for no bobbaunce
Yet was I neure with outen purueaunce
Of mariage nof other thynges eke
I holde a mouses herte nought worth a leke
That hath but oon hole for to sterte too
And yef that faille / than is al I doo /
I bare hym on honde he hadde enchaunted /me
My dame taught me that sotilte
And eke I seide I met of hym al nyght /
He wolde han slayn me / as I lay vp right /
And al my bedde was ful of verrey blood /
But yet I hope ye shal do me good /
For blood bytokeneth golde as me was taught /
And alle was fals I dremed of it right naught /
But as I folwed ay my dames lore
As wele of that as of other thynges more /
But now sire lat me see what shal I sayn
A ha ; by god I haue my tale agayn
Whan that my fourthe housbonde was on bere
I wepe algate and made sory chere
As wyfes moten / for it is vsage /
And with my kouꝰercheef couꝰered my visage
But for that I was purueyd of a make
I wepte but smal And that I vndirtake
To chirche was myn housbond born a morwe
With neighbours that for hym maden sorwe
And Iankyn oure clerke was oon of thoo
As helpe me god whan that I saugh hym goo
After the bere me thought he hadde a peire
Of legges and of feet so clene and faire
That al myn herte I yaf vn to his holde
He was I trowe twenty wynter olde
And I was fourty yef I shal sey soth
But yet I hadde alway a coltes tooth /
Gat tothed I was and that bycame me wele
I hadde the prynt of seint venus sele
As helpe me god I was a lusty oon
And faire and riche and yonge ⁊ wele bygoon
And trewely as myn housbondes tolde me
I hadde the best quoniam myght be /
For certes I am al veneryen
In felyng and myn hert is marcien
Venus me yaf my luste / my likerousnesse
And Mars yaf me / my stordy hardynesse
Myn ascendaunt was taure and Marce ther ynne
Allas Allas that euꝰer loue was synne
In folwyng ay myn inclinacion
Be vertue of my constellacion
That made me that I coude not withdrawe
My chaumber of venus from a good felawe
Yet haue I a marke of Mars vppon my face
And also in a nother pryue place
For god so wissely be my sauacion
I leued neuꝰer be noon diserecion
But euꝰer folwed myn Appetite
Al were he longe short blak or white
I toke no kepe so that he liked me
How pore he was ne of what degre
What sholde I say but at the mouthes ende
This Ioly Clerke Iankyn that was so hende
Hath weddid me with greet solempnyte
And to hym yaf I bothe lond and fee
That euꝰer was yeue me therfore /
But aftirward me repentid it ful sore
He nolde suffre no thyng of my lyst
By god he smote me ones on the lyst
For that I rent out of his book a leef
That of the strooke myn ere was al deef
Stybourn I was as is a lyonesse
And of my tonge a verrey Iangleresse
And walke I wolde as I had doon by forn
From hous to hous al though he had it sworn
For whiche he often tymes he wold preche
And me olde Romayn gestes teche
How he Symplicius Gallus lafte his wyf
And hire forsoke terme of alle his lyf
Nought but for open heueded he hir say
Lokyng out at his dore vpon a day /
An other Romayn tolde he me by name
That for his wif was at a someres game
With outen his wyttyng he forsoke hire eke /
And thanne wolde he vpon his bible seeke
That ilke prouꝰerbe of ecclesiaste
Where he cōmmaundeth and forbedeth faste
Man shal not suffre his wyf go royle a boute /
Than wolde he sey right thus (wtith outen doute)
Who so that bylldeth his hous al of salwes
And priketh his blynde hors ouꝰer the falwes
And suffreth hys wyf to go seken halwes
Is worthy to be honged on the galwes
But al for nought I sette nat an hawe
Of his ꝓprouerbes ne of his olde sawe
Ne I wolde nat of hym corrected be
I hate hem that my vices tellen me
And so doo moo god wote of vs than I
This made hym with me wood al outrely
I nolde nat forbere hym in no caas /
Now wole I sey yow soth by seynt Thomas
Why that I rent outo of his boke a leef
For whiche he smote me so that I was def /
He hadde a book that gladly nyght and day
For his disporte he wolde rede alway
He clepid it valerye and Theofraste
At whiche book he lough alway ful faste
And eke ther was somtyme a Clerke at Rome
A Cardinal that hight Ierome
That made a book a gayn Iouynyan
In whiche book eke ther was Tertulan
Crisippus Trotula and helowys
That was Abbesse nought fer fro parys
And eke the parables of Salamon
Ouydes arte and bokes many oon
And alle these were bounden in oo volume
And euꝰery nyght and day was his custume
Whan he hadde layser and vacacioun
From other wordly occupacioun
To reden in this booke of wikked wyues
He knewe of hem mo legendes and lyues
Than ben of good wyues in the bible
For trusteth wele it is an inpossible
That any clerke wil speke good of wyues
But yef it be of holy seintes lyues
Nof noon other wōmman neuꝰer the moo
Who peynted the leoun telle me whoo ;
By god yef women hadde writen stories
They wolde haue writen of men more wickednesse
Than al the merke of Adam may redresse
As Clerkes han with ynne here oratories
The Children of Mercurye and venus
Ben in hire wirkyng ful contrarious
Mercurie loueth wisdom and science
And venus loueth riot and dispence
And for hire dyuers disposicioun
Eche failleth in otheris exaltacioun
As thus / god wote Mercurie is desolat
In pisces where venus is exaltat
And venus failleth where Mercurie is reysed
Therfore no woman of no clerke is preised
The Clerke whan he is olde ⁊ may nought doo
Of venus werkys worth his olde shoo
Thanne sitte he doun and writeth in his dotage
That wemen kan not kepe hire mariage /
But now to purpos why I tolde the
That I was beten for a book parde /
Vpon a nyght Iankyn that was oure sire
Radde on his book as he sate by the fire
Of Eua first / that for hire wykkednesse
Was al mankynde brought to wrecchidnesse
For whiche that Ihu Crist was slayn
That bought vs with his hert blood a gayn /
Lo here expresse of wymen may ye fynde
What woman was the losse of al mankynde /
Tho redde he me how Sampson lost his heres
Slepyng his lēmman kyt it with hire sheres
Thourgh whiche tresoun loste he both his eyen /
Thoo redde he me yef I shal not leyen
Of Hercules and of Dyanyre
That caused hym to sette hym selfe a fyre /
Nothyng forgate he the care and woo
That Socrates hadde with hys wyues twoo
How Xantipa caste pisse vppon his heed
This sely man satte stille as he were deed
He wipt hys heed / no more durst he sayn /
But or that thonder stynt / cometh a rayn /
Of Phasipha that was the quene of Crete
For shrewidnesse hym thought the tale swete /
Fy speke nomore it is a grysly thyng
Of Orrible luste and hire lykyng
Of Clitermystra for hire leccherie
That falsly made hire housbond for to dye /
He redde it with ful good deuocyoun
He tolde me eke for what occasyoun
Amphiorax at Thebes lost his lyfe /
Myn housbond hadde a legend of his wife
Exiphilem / that for a nouche of golde
Hath pryuely vn to the Grekes tolde
Where that hire housbond hidde hym in a place
For whiche he hadde at Thebes sory grace /
Of lyuia tolde he me and of lucye
They bothe made hire housbondes for to dye /
That oon for loue / that other for haate /
Lyuia hire housbonde on an euen late
Enpoisoned hath for that she was his foo
Lucia likerous loued hire housbond soo
ffor that for he sholde alway vppon hire thynke
She yafe hym suche a maner loue drynke
That he was deed or it was by the morwe /
And thus Algates housbondes hadden sorwe /
Than tolde he me how oon latumyus
Complayned vn to his felawe Arryus
That in his gardyne growid suche a tree
On which he saide how that hys wyfes three
Honged hem selfe for hertes despetous /
O leue brother quod this Arryus
Yef me a plante of thilke blyssed tree
And in myn gardyn planted shal it bee /
Of latter date of wyues hath he
That some han slayn hire housbondes in hire bedde
And late hire lecchour dight hire al the nyght
While that the corps lay in the flore vpright /
And some haue dryven nailes in hire brayn
While that they sleep and thus thay han hem slayn /
Some haue youe hem poison in here drynke /
He spakke more harme than hert may bythynke /
And ther with alle he knewe moo prouerbes
Than in this worlde ther growen grasse or herbes /
Bet is quod he thyn habitacioun
Be with a leoun or a foule dragoun
Than with a woman vsyng for to chide /
Bet is quod he hiegh in the roof abyde
Than with a wikked woman doun in the hous
They ben so wikked and contrarious
They haten that hire housbondes loueth ay /
He saide a woman caste hire shame a way
Whan she cast of her smokke / and forther mo
A faire woman but she be chaste also
Is lyke a gold ryng in a sowes ere nose /
Who wolde wene or who wolde suppose /
The woo that in myn hert was and pyne /
And whan I sey he wolde neuꝰer fyne
To reden on this cursed book al nyght
Al sodenly .iij. leues haue I plight
Oute of his boke right as he redde ; and eke
I with my fyst so toke hym on the cheke
That in oure fire he felle bakward a doun /
And he vp sterte as doth a wood leoun
And with his fiste he smote me on the heed
That in the flore I lay as I were deed /
And whan he saugh how stille that I lay
He was a gaste and wolde haue fledde a way
Til atte laste oute of my swough I brayde
O hastow slayn me fals theef / I sayde /
And for my lande thus hastowe morthered me ;
Or I be deed / yet wole I kysse the /
And nerre he come and kneled faire a doun /
And seide dere syster Alysoun
As helpe me god I shal the neuꝰer smyte /
That I haue doon it is thy selue to wite
Foryeue it me and that I the beseke /
And yet efte sones I hitte hym on the cheke
And saide theef thus mothe I me wreke /
Now wole I deye I may no lenger speke /
But atte laste with mochel care and woo
We fille accorded by vs seluen twoo
He yaf me al the bridel in myn honde
To haue the gouꝰernaunce of hous and londe
And of his tonge and of his hoond also
And made hym brenne his book a noon right tho /
And whan that I hadde geten vn to me
By maistrie al the soueraignete
And that he seide myn owne trewe wyf
Do as the luste the terme of al thy lyf
Kepe thyn honour and kepe eke myn estate /
Aftir that day we hadde neure debate /
God helpe me so I was to hym as kynde
As ony wyfe from Denmarke vn to ynde
And also trewe and so was he to me
I pray to god that sitte in mageste
To blysse his soule for his mercy dere /
Now wole I sey my tale . yif ye wil here /
Here maketh ye frere an interrupcou of ye wyfes tale
The frere loughe whan he had herde al this
Now dame quod he so haue I Ioye or blys
This is a longe pꝰeramble of a tale /
And whenne the Sompnour herd the frere gale
Lo quod the Sompnour goddys Armes twoo
A frere wole entremete hym euꝰer moo
Lo good men a flye and eke a frere
Wille falle in euꝰery dysshe and matere /
What / spekest thow of pꝰerambulacioun ;
What / Aumble or trotte / or pees / or goo sit doun /
Thow lettist oure disporte in this manere /
Ye / wiltow soo sire Sompnour quod the frere ;
Now by my feith I shal or that I goo
Telle of a Sompnorur suche a tale or twoo /
That alle the folke shal laughen in this place /
¶ Now ellys frere I wille by shrewe thy face
Quod this Sompnour and I be shrewe me
But if I telle tales twoo or three
Of frerys or I come to Sydyngbourne
That I shal make thyn herte for to mourne /
For wele I wote thy pacience is goon /
Oure ooste cride pees / and that a noon /
And seide late the woman telle hire tale /
Ye faren as folke that dronken ben of ale /
Do dame / telle forth youre tale and that is beste /
Al redy sire quod she / right as yow lest /
Yef I haue licence of this worthy frere /
Yis dame quod he / telle forth and I wille here /
Here endeth the ꝓprologe of the tale
