l.hi: Chaucer de casibz viror illustriūn

div.l: Whan ended was the tale of Melibe
And of Prudence ⁊ hire benyygnyte
Oure ooste seyde . as I am feithful man
And by þtat pꝰercious corpus Madrian
I hadde leuer thanne a barel ale
That goodlef my wife hadde herde this tale
She nys nothynge of suche pacience
As was this Melibeus wife Prudence .
By goddes bones . whan I bete my knaues .
She brengeth me the greet clobbed staues
And crieth . slee the dogges euꝰerychou .
And breke hem bothe bakke ⁊ euꝰery bou .
And if that any neighebore of myne .
Wole nat in chirche to my wife enclyne
Or be so hardi to hire to hire to trespace
Whan she cometh . she raumpeth in my face
And crieth / fals to wards / wreke thy wife
By corpus bones I wole haue thy knyfe
And þu shalt haue my distaf ⁊ goo spynne
Fro day to nyght . right thus she wole begynne
Allas she seith . þtat euꝰer þtat I was shape
To wedde a melksoppe . or a cowarde ape
That wole ben ouꝰer ladde / wtith euꝰery wight
Thow darste nat stonden by þi wyues right
This is my . lyfe . but if that I wole fight
And oute atte dore a noon I moot me dight
Or ellys I am but loste . but if that I
Be like a wilde leou / fool hardy
I woot wele she wole do me slee som day
Som neighebore . and thanne go my way
For I am ꝑperilous with knyfe in honde
Al be it that I dare nat hire withstonde
For she is bigg in armes by my feith
That shalle he fynde . þtat hire mysdooth or seith
But late vs passe a way . fro this matere
My lorde the Monke qd he be mery of chere
For ye shulle telle a tale trewely
Loo Rouchestre stont here fast by
Ride forth myn owen lorde breke nat oure game
But by my trouthe I knowe nat youre name
Wheþꝰer shal I calle yow my lorde . dame Iohn
Or daun Thomas . or elles Daun Albon
Of what hous be ye . be youre fader kyn
I vowe to god ; þu haste a full faire skyn
Yt is a gentil pasture . ther thow goost
Thow arte nat lyke a penaunt or a goost
Vppon my feith . thow arte som officer
Som worthy sextein . or som Celerer
For by my faders soule as to my dome
Thow arte a maister whan þu arte at home
No pore Cloistrer . ne no Novys
But a gouꝰernoure witti ⁊ wys
And ther . with al of brawnes ⁊ of bones
A wele faryng ꝑpersone for the nones
I preye to god yeue hym confusiou
That firste the brought vnto religion
Thow woldest han bene a tredefoule aright
Haddest þu as greet a leue as þu haste myght
To ꝑperfourme all thy luste in engendrure
Thow haddest bygeten full many a creature
Allas why werestow so wide a cope
God yeue me sorwe . but ⁊ I were a pope
Nat oonly þu . but euꝰery myghty man
Though he were shore full hye vppon his pan
Sholde haue a wife / for al the werlde is lorn /
Religioun hath take vp alle the corn
Of tredynge . ⁊ we borel men ben shrympes
Of feble trees ; there come wrecched Impes
This maketh that oure eires beth so sklender
And feble that thay may nat wele engender
This maketh that oure wyues wole assay
Religious folke . for ye mowe bettre pay
Of venus paiementz than may we
God woot no lussheburgh payen ye
But be nat wrooth my lorde though that I pleye
Full ofte in game a sooth I haue herde seye
This worthy Monke toke all in paceince
And seide I wole doon al my diligence
As fer as sowneth in to honestee
To telle yow a tale / or twoo or three
And if þu lyste to herkne hiderwarde
I wole yow sey the lyfe of seint Edwarde
Or ellys first tragedies / wole I telle
Of whiche I haue an hundred in my selle
Tragedye is to seyn a certeyn storie
As olde bokes maken vs memorie
Of hym stood in greet ꝓprosꝑperite
And is y fallen oute of heigh degre
In to miserie ⁊ endeth wrecchedly
And they ben vꝰercified comonly
Of vj . feet . whiche men clepen exametron
In prose eke ben endited many oon
And eke in metre in many a sondry wise
Loo this declarynge oughte ynow suffise
Now herkeneth if yow lyke for to here
But first I yow beseke in this matere
Though I be ordre telle nat these thynges
Be it of Popes Emꝑperours or kynges
Aftir hire ages as men writen fynde
But telle hem som byfore ⁊ som byhynde
As it now cometh / vnto my remembraunce
Haue me excused of myn ignoraunce

l.hi: Explicit ꝓprohemiūnm
⁊ Incipit Fabula

div.l: I wole by waile in manꝰere of tregedye
The harme of hem þtat stood in heigh degre
And fellen so that ther nas no remedie
To brynge hem oute of hire aduꝰersite
For certeyn whan þtat fortune lyste to flee
Be ware be these ensamples trewe ⁊ olde
¶ At lucifer though he an Aungel were
And nat a man . at hym I wole begynne
For though fortune way non Aungel dere
From heighe degre . yet felle he for his synne
Doun in to helle where as he yet is ynne
O lucifer brightest of Aungels alle
Now art thow Sathanas . þtat maist nat twynne
Oute of miserie . in whiche þtat þu art falle
¶ Lo Adam in the felde of Damyssene
With goddis owne fynger wrought was he
And not bygoten of mannes sparme vnclene
And welth all paradis sauyng oo tree
Had neuꝰer wordly man so highe degree
As Adam till he for mysgouꝰernaunce
Was dryue oute of his hie ꝓpropsꝑperite
To labour ⁊ to helle and myschaunce
Loo Sampsoūn whiche þtat was anuciat
By þe Aungel longe or his natiuite
And was to god almyghti consecrat
And stood in noblesse while he myght se
Was neuꝰer swiche a nother as was he
To speke of strengthe ⁊ ther wtith hardynesse
But to his wyues tolde he his secre
Thurgh whiche he slow hym selfe for wrecchednesse
// Sampsou þs noble []andand myghti champioun
With outen wepne saue his hondes tweye
He slow ⁊ all to rente þe leoun
Towarde his weddyng walkyng by þe weye
His fals wife coude hym so plese ⁊ preye
Til she his counseile knewe / ⁊ she vntrewe
Vnto his foos bygan to wreye
And hym forsook ⁊ tooke a nother newe
¶ The hundred foxes toke Sampsou for yre
And alle hire tailles to gidre bonde
And sette þe foxes tailles alle on fire
For he on euꝰery taille . hadde knytte a broonde
And they brende alle þe Cornes in that londe
And alle hire Olyues ⁊ vynes eke
A thousand men he slough wtith his hoonde
⁊ hadde no wepne but an asses cheke
¶ Whan they were slayn / so thursted hy þtat he
Was welle nyghe lorne for whiche he gan to preye
That god wolde on his peyne han som pite
And sende hym som drynke . or ellys moste he deye
And of þs asses cheke / that was dreye
Oute of a wange tooth . sprange a noon a welle
Of whiche he dranke y now . shortly to seye
Thus heelpe hym god . as Iudicum kan telle
¶ By verrey force at Gazon on a nyght
Maugre Philistiens of þtat Citee
The gates of þe toun he hath vp plight
And on his bakke y karied hem hath he
Highe on an hille / where as men myght hem se
O noble tl myghti sampson leef ⁊ dere
Hadde þu not tolde to wōmmen thy secre
In alle this worlde ne hadde ben thy pere
¶ This Sampson neuꝰer Cider dranke ne wyn
Ne on his heed com rasour noon ne shere
By pꝰercepte of the messenger dyuyn
For alle his strengthes in his heres were
And fully xxtiri . wynter yere by yere
He hadde of Israel þe gouꝰernaunce
But soone shall he wepe many a tere
For wōmmen shulle hym brynge to myschaunce
¶ Vnto his lēmman dalida he tolde
That in heeris alle his streyngthe lay
And falsly to his foomen / he hym solde
And slepyng in hire barme vpon a day
She made to clippe / or sheer his heer a way
And made his fomen all þs crafte espien
And whan that thay hym fonde in þs array
They bounden hym faste . ⁊ putte oute his eyen
¶ But eer his heer was clipped or y shaue
Ther was noo bonde . wtith whiche men myght hym bynde
But now is he in prisoun in a Caue
Where as they made hym at þe querne grynde
O noble Sampsou strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge / in glorie ⁊ in richesse
Now maistow wepen wtith thyn eyen blynde
Sith þu froo wele arte falle in wrecchednesse
The ende of þs caitife . was as I shal sey
His foomen made a feste vpon a day
And made hym as hire fole / byfore hem pleye
And þs was in a temple of gret array
But at þe laste he made a foule a fray
For he twoo pilers shoke ⁊ made hem falle
And doun felle temple ⁊ alle / ⁊ ther it lay
And slowe hym selfe ⁊ eke his fomen alle
¶ This is to seyn þe princes euꝰerychou
And eke three thousand bodies were there sleyn
Wtith fallyng of the greet temple of stoon
Of Sampson now wole I nomore saynseynsaeyn
Beth ware / by this ensample olde ⁊ pleyn
That no men telle here counsel til hire wyues
Of swiche thynge as they wole han secre fayn
Yf that it touche hire lymes or hir lyues
¶ Of hercules the souꝰereyn conqueroure
Syngen hise werkes ; laude ⁊ heigh renoun
For in his tyme of strengthe he bare þe floure
He slough ⁊ rafte þe skyn fro the leoun
He of Centauros . leyde þe boost a doun
He Arpies slough . the cruel briddes felle
He golden Apples / rafte of the dragoun
He drough oute Cerberus / the hounde of helle
¶ He slough the cruel tyraunt Busirus
And made his hors to frete hym flesshe ⁊ boon
He slow þe firy serpent venymus
Of Achilles twoo hornes he brake oon
And he slowe Kakus in a Caue of stoon
He slowe the geaunt Antheu9 þe stronge
He slough þe grysly boor . ⁊ þtat a noon
And bare the hede ; on his nekke longe
¶ Was neuꝰer wight sith that þs worlde bigan
That slow many monstres as did he
Thurgh oute þs wilde worlde his name ran
What for hise strengthe / ⁊ for heigh bounte
And euꝰery reaume went he for to se
He was so stronge that noman myght hym lette
At bothe the worldes endes / seith Trophee
In stide of boundes he a piler sette
¶ A leman hadde this noble champion
That highte dianra fresshe as may
And as these Clerkes . maken mencou
She hath hym sente a sherte fresshe ⁊ gay
Allas þs sherte . allas ⁊ weile a way
Enuenemed was so subtily wtith alle
That er that he hadde werid it halfe a day
It made his fleisshe alle from his bones falle
¶ But nartheles som clerkes hire excusen
By oon that hight Nessus that it maked
Be it as be may I wole nat hire accusen
But on his bakke he wered the sherte al naked
Til that his fleisshe was for the venym blaked
And whan he say non other remedye
In hote coles . he hath hym selfen raked
For with noo venym / deigned hym to dye
¶ Thus starfe þs worthy myghty hercules
Lo whoo may truste on fortune any throwe
For hym þtat folweth all þs worlde of prees
Er he beware is ofte y leide full lowe
Full wys is he . that kan hym siluen knowe
Beth ware / for whan fortune lyste to glose
Than waiteth she hir man to ouꝰer throwe
By swiche a wey / as he wole leest suppose
¶ The myghty trone / the precious tresor
¶ The glorious ceptre / ⁊ roial maieste
That hadde þe kyng . Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnnethe . may discryued be
He twies wan Ierusalem the Cite
The vessel of the temple he wtith hym ladde
At Babiloyne / was his souꝰereyne see
In whiche / his glorie ⁊ his delyte he hadde
¶ The fairest children of the blood roial
Of Israel he leet / do gelde anon
And maked iche of hem to ben his thral
Amonges othere Danyel was oon
That was the wisest childe of euꝰerychou
For he the dremes of þe kyng expowned
Where as in chaldey / Clerke ne was ther noon
That wiste to what fyne . his dremes sowned
¶ This proude kyng / leet make a statue of golde
Sixti cubitis longe ⁊ seuene in brede
To whiche ymage / he bothe yonge ⁊ olde
Cōmmaunded to loute / ⁊ haue in drede
Or in a Furneys / ful of flambes rede
He shall be bronde þtat wolde nought obeye
But neuꝰer wolde assente to that dede
Danyel . ne his yonge felawes tweye
¶ This kynge of kynges proude was ⁊ elate
He wende that god that sitte in maieste
Ne myght hym nat byreue of his estate
But sodeynly he leste his dignyte
And like a beest hym semed for to be
And eet hey as an oxe . ⁊ lay ther oute
In rayn with wilde bestes walked he
Til certeyn tyme was I come a boute
¶ And like an Egles fetheris waxe his heeris
His nailes like a briddes clawes were
Til god relessed hym a certeyn yeris
And yaf hym witte ⁊ than wtith many a tere
He thonked god ⁊ euer his life in fere
Was he to doon amys . or more trespace
And til that tyme . he leyde was on his bere
He knewe that god was full of myght ⁊ grace
¶ His sone whiche that hight Baltasar
That helde the reigne aftir his fader day
¶ By ~ his Fader koude nat be ware
For proude he was / of herte ⁊ of a ray
And eke an Idolastre was he ay
His highe estate assured hym in pride
But fortune caste hym doun ⁊ ther he lay
And sodeīngly his reigne gan . dyuyde
¶ A feeste he made vnto his lordes alle
Vpon a tyme ⁊ made hem blithe be
And thanne his officers gan he calle
Gooth bryngeth foorth the vessels qd he
Whiche that my fader in his ꝓprosꝑperite
Oute of the temple of Ierlm byrafte
And to oure highe goddis thanke we
Of honour that oure eldres wtith vs laste
¶ His wyfe / his lordes ⁊ his concubynes
Ay dronken while þtat hire Appetytes lafte
Oute of these vessels sondry wynes
And on a walle this kynge his eyen caste
And say an hande armles . that wroot ful faste
For feer of whiche he quook ⁊ siked sore
This hand that made baltasar so soore a gaste
Wroot Mane techel phares . ⁊ namore
¶ In alle that lande Magicien was ther noon
That coude expounde / what þs lettre mente
But Danyel / expounde it a noon
And seide kynge god thy fader lente
Glorie / ⁊ honour / regne / tresour / rente
And he was proude . ⁊ nothyng god ne dradde
And therfore god grete wreche vpon hym sente
And hym byrefte the reigne that he hadde
¶ He was oute caste of mann9 companye
With asses was hise habitacou
And eet hey as a beste in weet ⁊ drye
Til that he knewe by grace ⁊ by resou
That god of heuene hath dominaciou
Ouꝰer euꝰery reigne / ⁊ euery creature
Than hadde godde of hym compassion
And hym restored his reigne ⁊ his figure
¶ Eke thow þtat arte his sone art proude also
And knowest alle these thynges verrayly
And arte rebel to god ⁊ art his foo
Thow dranke eke of þe vessel boldely
Thy wife eke ⁊ thy wenches synfully
Dronke of thoo same vessels sondry wynes
And heriest fals goddis cursedly
Therfore to þe y shapen / full grete peyne is
¶ This hande was sente from god / þtat on þe walle
Wroot Mane techel phares . truste me
Thy reigne is doon þu weiest nought at alle
Dyuyded is thy regne . ⁊ it shal be
To Mede ⁊ to ꝐPerses . yeuen qd he
And thilke same nyght . this kynge was slawe
And Darius occupieth his degree
Though he therto . hadde neither right ne lawe
¶ Lordynges ensample herby may ye take
How that in lordshep is no sikernesse
For whanne Fortune wole a man forsake
She berith a wey his reigne ⁊ his richesse
And eke his frendes booth more ⁊ lesse
For what man that hath frendes thorow fortune
Mishap wole make hem enemys I gesse
This ꝓprouerbe is soth ⁊ full comune
¶ Cenobia of Palymere quene
As writen ꝐPersiens / of hire noblesse
So worthy []sheshe was / in armes ⁊ so kene
That no wight passed hire / in hardynesse
Ne in lynage / ne other gentellesse
Of kynges blood of ꝐPerce / is she descended
I sey nat that she hadde moost fairnesse
But of hire shappe she myght nat ben amended
¶ From hire childhede I fynde that she fledde
Office of wōmmen . ⁊ to wode she wente
And many a wilde hertes blood she shedde
With arwes brood that she to hem sente
She was so swifte that shee a noon hem hente
And whan that she was elder . she wolde kille
Lyons leopardes . and beres alto rente
And in here Armes welde hem at hire wille
¶ She dorste / wilde beestes dennes seke
And rennen in þe Mounteyns al the nyght
And slepen vndir the busshe . ⁊ she coude eke
Wrastlen by verrey force . ⁊ by verrey myght
With a yonge man were he neuꝰer so wight
Ther myght no thynge in hire armes stonde
She kepte hire maidenhede from euꝰery wight
To no man deigned hire to be bonde
¶ But at the laste hire frendes haue hire maried
To Onedake a prince of that cuntre
Alle were it soo þtat shee hem longe taried
And ye shalle vnderstonde . how that he
Hadde swiche fantasies . as hadde she
But natheles / when they were knyt in fere
They lyued in Ioye . ⁊ in felicite
For iche of hem hadde other liefe ⁊ dere
¶ Saue oo thynge þtat she wolde neuꝰer assente
By no wey that he sholde by hir lye
But oones for it was hire pleyne entent
To haue a childe the world to multiplie
And also sone . as þtat she myght espye
That she was nat with childe with that dede
Thanne wolde she suffren hym don his fantasye
Eft sones . ⁊ nought but ones oute of drede
¶ And if she were wtith childe at thilke caste
Nomore sholde he pleien thilke game
Til fully xl daies . weren paste
Than wolde she oones soffre hym do the same
Al were this Onedake . wilde or tame
He gate nomore of hire / for thus she seide
It was to wyues leccherie ⁊ shame
In oother caas / if that men wtith hem pleide
¶ Two sones by thys Onedake hadde she
The whiche she kepte . in vꝰertue ⁊ lettrure
But now vnto oure tale turne we
I seye so worshepfull a creature
And wys ther with . ⁊ large wtith mesure
So peyneble in the werre . ⁊ curteys eke
Ne more labore myght in werre endure
Was noon / thow al this world men sholde seke
¶ Hire riche array . ne myght nat be tolde
As wele in vessel as in hire clothynge
She was alle cladde in perre ⁊ in golde
And eke she lafte nought for non huntynge
To haue of sundry tonges ful knowynge
Whan that she leyser hadde / ⁊ for to entende
To lerne bokes was alle hire lykyng
How she in vertue myght here lyfe despende
¶ And shortly of this storie for to trete
So doughty was hire housbonde ⁊ eke she
That they conquered many reignes grete
In Thorient with many a faire Cite
Aꝑpertenant vnto the maieste
Of Rome ⁊ wtith stronge honde helde hem ful faste
Ne neuꝰere myght her fomen doon hem flee
Ay while that Onydakes daies laste
¶ Hire batailles who so lyste hem for to rede
Agayn Sapor þe kyng ⁊ other moo
And how that alle this ꝓprocesse fille in dede
Whi she conquered ⁊ what title ther too
And aftir of hire myschyef ⁊ hire woo
How that she was biseged ⁊ y take
Late hym / vnto my maister Petrak goo
That writ I now of this I vndir take
¶ Whan Onedake was deed / she myghttely
The regnes helde . ⁊ wtith hire ꝓpropre honde
Agayns hire foos / she faught so cruelly
That ther nas kynge ne prince in al that londe
That he nas glad if he that grace fonde
That she ne wolde . vppon his londe werreye
With hire they made alliaunce by boond
To ben in pees . ⁊ lete hire ride ⁊ pleye
¶ The Emꝑperoure of Rome Claudius
Ne hym byforn the Romayn Galyen
Ne dursten neuꝰer ben so corageus
Ne noon Ermyn ne non Egipcien
Ne Surrien ne noon Arabien
Wtith Inne þe feldes þtat durste wtith hire . fight
Leste that she wolde hem wtith hire handes slen
Or with hire meyne puttēm hem to flyght
¶ In kynges habit wenten hire sones two
As heires of hire fadres regnes alle
And heramanno . and Thymalao
Hire names were as Persiens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in hire hony galle
This myghty quene may no while endure
Fortune oute of hire reigne made hire falle
To wrecchidnesse ⁊ to mysauenture
¶ Aurelian whan that þe gouꝰernaunce
Of Rome come in to his handes tweye
He shooꝑper vppon this quene to doon vengeaunce
And wtith his legions he toke his weye
Towarde Cenobie . ⁊ shortly for to seye
He made hire flee and atte þe laste hir hente
And fettrid hire ⁊ eke hire children tweye
And wanne the lande ⁊ hoome to Rome he went
¶ Amonges other thynges that he wan
Here chare that was wtith golde wroght ⁊ perre
This grete Romayn this Aurelian
Hath with hym ladde / for that men sholde it se
Byforne his tryumphe walketh she
With gilte cheynes on hir nekke hangynge
Crowned was she / as aftir hire degre
And full of perre . charged hire clothynge
¶ Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredfull to kynges . ⁊ to Emꝑperoures
Now gawreth all the peple on hire allas
And she that helmed was . in starke stoures
And wanne by force townes stronge ⁊ towres
Shall on hyre heed ; now were a vitremyte
And she that baar the sceptre full of floures
She bare a distafe hir coste for to quyte
¶ Al though that Nero were vicious
As any fende that lith full low a doun
Yet he . as tellith vs swetonius
This wide worlde hadde in subieccioun
Booth este ⁊ weste North . ⁊ Septemtrion
Of Rubies Saphires . ⁊ of pierles white
Were []allealle hire clothes broudid vp ⁊ doun
For he in gēmmes gretly gan delite
¶ More delicat more pompous of aray
More proude . was neuꝰer emꝑperour than he
That ilke clooth . that he hadde werid o day
Aftir that tyme he wolde it neuꝰer see
Nettes of golde threed hadde he greet plente
To fisshe in Tybre water whan hym lyst pleye
Hise lustes were al lawe in his decree
For fortune as his frende hym wolde obeye
¶ He Rome brende for hise delicacie
The Senatours he slowe vpon a day
To here how that men wolde wepe ⁊ crye
And slough his brother ⁊ by his suster lay
His moder he made in pitous array
For he hire wombe slytte to byholde
Where he conseyued so weylaway
That he so litel / of his moder tolde
¶ No tere oute of his eighen . for that sight
Ne cam / but seide a faire woman was she
Greet wondir is / how that he coude or myght
Be domesman / of hire dede beaute
The wyn to bryngen hym cōmmaunded he
And dranke a noon noon other woo he made
Whan myght is ioyned vnto cruelte
Allas to depe wole the venym wade
¶ In youthe / a maister hadde this Emꝑperoure
To teche hym lettrure ⁊ curtesie
For of Moralite he was the floure
As in his tyme but if bokes lye
And while this maister hadde of hym maistrie
He maked hym . so louyng ⁊ so souple
That longe tyme it was / er tirannye
Or ony vice durste in hym vncouple
¶ This Seneca of whiche þtat I deuyse
Bi cause Nero / hadde of hym swiche drede
For he fro vices . wolde hym ay chastice
Discretly as by worde / ⁊ nat by dede
Sire wolde he seyn / an Emꝑperour moot nede
By vertuouse ⁊ hate Tirannye
For whiche []hehe in a bath made hym to blede
On bothe hys armes . til he most deye
¶ This Nero hadde eke . a custumance
In youthe agayns his maister forto rise
Whiche aftirwarde . hym thought a greet greuance
Ther for he maden hym deyen in this wise
But Natheles this Seneca the wise
Chees in a bath . to die in this manꝰere
Rather thanne han . a nother tormentrise
And thus hath Nero / slayn his maister dere
¶ Now felle it so . that Fortune lyste no lengere
The hie pride of Nero . to cherise
For though that he was stronge . yet was she strenger
She thought thus . by god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfilde of vice
In hie degree ⁊ Emꝑperour hym calle
By god oute of his sete I wole hym trice
Whan he leest weneth / sonnest shalle he falle
¶ The puple roos vppon hym / on a nyght
For his defaute / ⁊ whan he is espied
Oute of his dores a noon / he hath hym dight
Allone ⁊ there he wende han ben allied
He knokked faste / ⁊ ay the more he cried
The faster shette they the doores alle
Tho wiste he wele he hadde hym selfe mysgyed
And wente his wey . no lenger durste he calle
¶ The peple cride / and rombled vp ⁊ doun
That wtith his eeris . herde how they seide
Where is this fals Tiraunt this Neroin
For fere Almoost oute of his witte he breyde
And to his goddis pitously he preide
For socour . but it myght . be tyde
For drede of this hym thought þtat he dede
And ranne in to a gardeyn hym to hyde
¶ And in this gardyn . fonde he cherles twey
That seten by a fuyr grete ⁊ reed
And to these cherles two he gan prey
To slen hym . ⁊ to gerden of his heed
That to his body . whan that he were deed
Were no despit ydoon / for his defame
Hym selfe he slough he coude no bettre reed
Of whiche fortune . loughe ⁊ hadde a game
¶ Was neuꝰer Capitayn . vndir a kynge
That reignes moo put in subieccoūn
Ne strenger was in felde . of alle thynge
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompous in heigh pꝰersumpcoūn
Thanne Olyferne . whiche fortune ay kyste
So lykerously . and ladde hym vp ⁊ doun
Til that his heed was of er that he wiste
¶ Nat oonly that þs world hadde hym in awe
For lesynge of richesse or liberte
But made euꝰery man reney his lawe
Nabugodonosor / was god seide he
Noon other god . sholde adoured be
Agayns this heste / no wighte durste trespace
Saue in Bethulia / a stronge Cite
Where Eliachym / a preest was of that place
¶ But take kepe of the deeth of Oliferne
Amydde his ooste he dronke lay a nyght
Wtith ynne his tente . large as is a berne
And yet for alle his pompe ⁊ al his myght
Iudith a wōmman as he lay vp right
Slepyng his heed of smote ⁊ from his tente
Full pryuely she stale from euꝰery wight
And with his heed vnto hire tou she wente
¶ What nedeth it of kyng Anthiochus
To telle / his hie roial mageste
His hie pride his werkys venymus
For swiche a nother was ther noon as he
Reed whiche þtat he was in Machabee
And reed þe proude wordes that he seyde
And why he felle from hye ꝓprosꝑperite
And in an hille how wrecchidly he deyde
¶ Fortune hym hadde enchaunted so in pride
That verreily he wende he myght Atteyne
Vn to the sterres / vpon euꝰery side
And in balaunce weyen eche mountayne
And alle the floodes of the see restrayne
And goddes peple hadde he moost in hate
He wolde he slen / in turment ⁊ in peyne
Wenyng that god ne myght his pride abate
¶ And for that Nichanore / and Thymothee
With Iewes weren venquysshed myghtely
Vnto the Iewys / swiche an hate hadde he
That he bad greithe his chare ful hastely
And swore ⁊ seyde ful dispitously
Vnto Ierlm he wolde Efte soone
¶ God for his manace . hym so soore smot
With inuisible wounde ay incurable
That in his guttes / carfe it so ⁊ boot
That hise peynes weren importable
And certeynly / the wreche was resonable
For many a mannes guttes ded he peyne
But fro his purpos cursed ⁊ dampnable
For alle his smert he wolde hym nat restreyne
¶ But bade a noon apparaillen his hoste
And sodeynly er he were of it ware
God daunted al his pride / ⁊ alle his booste
For he so sore / fil out of his chare
That it his lymes / and his skyn to tare
So that he neither myght goo ne ride
But in a chaier / men aboute hym bare
Al forbrosed bothe bakke ⁊ side
¶ The wreche of god hym smote . so cruelly
That thourgh his bodye . wikked wormes crepte
And ther withal . he stanke so horribly
That noon of alle his meyne that hym kepte
Whether so he woke . or elles slepte
Ne myght not the stynke of hym endure
In this mescheef he wailed ⁊ eke wepte
And knewe god lorde of euꝰery creature
¶ To alle his ooste . ⁊ to him selfe also
Ful wlatsom was the stynke of his careyne
No man ne myght hym bere to ne fro
And in this stynke . and this horrible peyne
He starfe full wrecchedly in a mounteyne
Thus hath this robbour / and this homycyde
That many a man / made to wepe ⁊ pleyne
Swiche gerdon / as bylongeth vnto pride
The storie of Alisaunder is so comune
That euꝰery wight that hath discreciou
Hath herde somwhat / or alle of his fortune
This wide worlde / as in conclusiou
He wanne by strengthe . or for his hie renon
They were gladde / for pees vnto hym sende
The pride of man and beest he layde a doun
Where so he cam / vnto the worldes ende
Comꝑperison / myght neuꝰer yet ben maked
Bitwixe hym and another conquerour
For alle this worlde / for drede of hym hath quaked
He of knyghthode ⁊ of fredom floure
Fortune hym made the . heire of honoure
Saue wyn ⁊ wymen . no thynge myght a swage
His hie entente in armes to labour
So was he ful / of leonyn corage
What pris were it to hym though I yow tolde
Of Darius ⁊ of an hundred thowsand moo
Of kynges . Pirinces . Dukes . Erles bolde .
Whiche he conquered . ⁊ broght hem in to woo
I sey as fer as a man may ride ⁊ goo
The worlde was hise what sholde I more deuyse
For though I write . or tolde yow euꝰer moo
Of his knyghthode / it myght nat suffise
Twelfe yere he reigned as seith Machabe
Philippus sone of Macedoyne he was
That firste was kynge / in grece the cuntre
O worthy gentil Alisaunder allas
That euꝰer sholden falle swiche a cas
Enpoysened / of thyn owne folke þu were
Thy sys . fortune . hath turned in to aas
And for the / ne wepe she neuꝰer a tere
Who shalle me yeue teeris to compleyne
The deeth of gentilesse / ⁊ of fraunchise
That alle the worlde welded in his demeyne
And yet hym thought . it myght not suffise
So full was his corage . of heigh emprise
Allas whoo shall me helpe to endite
Fals fortune / ⁊ poysoūn to despise
The whiche two / of alle this woo I wite
By wisdom manhede ⁊ by greet labour
Fram humble bedde to Roial mageste
Vp roos . he Iulius the conquerour
That wanne alle the Occidente by lande ⁊ see
By strength of honde or ellys by trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributarie
And sith of Rome the Emꝑperour was he
Til that fortune waxe his aduꝰersarie
O myghti Cesar that in Thessalie
Agayn Pompeus Fader thyn in lawe
That of Thorient hadde alle the Chiualrie
As fer as that the day bygynneth dawe
Though thurgh thy knyghthode . haste hem take ⁊ slawe
Saue fewe folke that . with Pompeus fledde
Thurgh whiche thow puttest alle Thorient in awe
Thanke fortune that so wele the spedde
But now a litel while . I wole by wayle
This Pompeus . this noble gouꝰernour
Of Rome whiche that sleigh at this bataille
I sey oon of his men / a fals traitour
His heed of smote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius ⁊ hym the heed he brought
Allas Pompeie . of Thorient Conquerour
That fortune vnto swyche a fyn the brought
To Rome Agayn / repaireth Iulius
Wtith his triumphe laureat full hye
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euꝰer hadde of his heigh estate enuye
Full piriuely hath made conspiracie
Agayns this Iulius . in subtil wise
And caste the place in whiche he sholde dye
With boydekyns . as I shall yow deuyse
This Iulius to the Capitolie wente
Vpon a day as he was wonte to goon
And in the Capitolie a noon hym hente
This false Brutus . and his other foon
And stiked hym wtith boydekyns a noon
With many a wounde and thus they lete hym lye
But neuꝰer grunte he at noo strook but oon
Or ellys at two / but if his storie lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wele loued / estatly honeste
That though his deedly woundes so sore smerte
Hise mantel ouꝰer his hipes caste he
For noman sholde sen his pryuete
And as he lay / of dyeng in a traunce
And wiste verely that deed was he
Of honeste yet hadde he remembraunce .
Lucan to the this storie I recomende
And to sweton ⁊ to valerius alsoo
That of the storie / writen worde ⁊ ende
How that these greet Conquerours twoo
Fortune was firste frende ⁊ sith a foo
Noman []nene truste vpon hire fauour longe
But haue hire in a waite for euꝰer moo
Witnesse on alle these conquerours stronge
This riche Cresus . whilom kyng of lyde
Of whiche Cresus Cirus soore hym dradde
Yet was he caught amyddes alle his pride
And to be brende men to the fire hym ladde
But swiche a rayn doun fro the welken shadde
That slow the fuyr . ⁊ made hym to escape
But to be ware . no grace yet he hadde
Til fortune . on the galwes made hym gape
Whan he eschaped was / he kan nat stente
Forto bygynne a newe werre a gayn
He wende wele for that fortune hym sente
Swiche happe that he escaped thurgh the rayn
That of his foos he myght nat be slayn
And eke a sweuen vpon a nyght / he mette
Of whiche he was // proude ⁊ eke so fayn
That in vengeaunce he alle his herte sette
Vpon a tree he was as that hym thoughte
Ther Iuppitꝰer hym wesshe bothe bakke ⁊ side
And Pheb9 eke a faire towail hym broughte
To drye hym with / and therfore waxe his pride
And to his doughter þtat stood hym byside
Whiche that he knewe in heigh sentence habounde
He bade hire telle hym what it signified
And she his dreem / bygan right thus expounde
¶ The tree qd shee the galwes is to mene
And Iuppiter bitokeneth snow ⁊ reyn
And Pheb9 wit his towail so clene
Tho ben the sonnes stremes / for to seyn
Thow shalte an honged be fader certeyn
Rayn shall the waisshe . ⁊ sonne shall the drie
Thus warned hym . full plat ⁊ full pleyn
His doughter . whiche that was Phanye
An . hanged was Cresus the proude kynge
His Roial trone myght hym nat auaile
Tragedies noon oother maner thynge
Ne kan in syngyng crie ne bywaile
But that fortune alway wole assaille
With vnwar strook the regnes that ben proude
For whan men trusteth hire . than wole she faile
And kouere hire bright face with a clowde
¶ O noble o worthy Petro / glorie of Spaigne
Whom fortune helde so heigh in mageste
Wele oughten men thy pitous deth complayne
Oute of thy lande thy brother made the flee
And aftir that a sige by subtilite
Thow were bitraised ⁊ ladde vnto his tente
Where as he with his owen honde . slow the
Succedynge in thyn reigne ⁊ in thyn rente
¶ The feeld of snowe / wtith thegle of blak ther Inne
Caught . wtith the lymrod / coloured as the glede
He brewe this cursidnesse / ⁊ alle this synne
The wikked neste / was werkere of this nede
Nought Charles . Olyuere that toke ay hede
Of trouthe ⁊ honour but Armoryke
Genylon . Olyuere . corrupte for mede
Brought this worthy kynge in swiche a brike
¶ O worthy Petro . kynge of Cipre also
That Alisaunder wan by hie maistrye
Full many an hethen . wroughtest þu ful woo
Of whiche thyn owen liges hadde enuye
And for no thynge / but for thy chiualrie
They in thy bedde / han slayn the by the morwe
Thus kan fortune hire whele gouerne ⁊ gye
And oute of Ioye brynge men to sorwe
¶ Of Melan / grete Barnabo viscounte
God of delyt ⁊ scourge of lumbardie
Why sholde I not thyn Infortune acounte
Sith in estaat thow clombe were so hye
Thy brother sone . that was thy double allie
For he thy nevewe was ⁊ sone in lawe
With Inne his prison made the to die
But why ne how / noot I . þtat þu were slawe
¶ Of the Erle hugelyn of Pize the langoure
Ther may no tunge tellen for pite
But litel oute of Pize stant a toure
In whiche toure in prison putte was hee
And with hym ben his litel children three
The eldeste scarsly fyve yere was of age
Allas fortune it was grete Cruelte
Swiche briddes to putte in swiche a cage
¶ Dampned was he to deye in that prisoun
For Roger whiche that bisshop was of pize
Hadde on hym made a fals suggestion
Thurgh whiche the peple gan vpon hym ryse
And putten hym / to Prisoun in swiche wise
As ye han herde . ⁊ mete ⁊ drynke he hadde
So smal . that wele vnneth it may suffise
And ther withal / it was ful pore ⁊ badde
¶ And on a day byfel / that in that houre
Whan that his mete wonte was to be brought
The Gailler shette the dores of the toure
He herde it wele . but he spake right nought
And in his herte anon ther felle a thought
That they for hunger . wolde doon hym deyen
Allas qd he . allas that I was wrought
Ther with the teeris fillen from his eighen
¶ Hise yonge sone that three yere was of age
Vnto hym seide . Fader . Fader . why do ye wepe
Whan wole the Gailler brynge oure potage
Ys there no mosel brede that yee do kepe
I am so hungry that I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I myghte slepe euere
Thanne shulde not hunger in my wombe crepe
Ther is no thynge but breed that me were leuere
¶ Thus day by day the childe bygan to crie
Til on his Fadres barme . a doun it lay
And seide fare wele Fader I moot dye
And kiste his Fader . ⁊ deyde the same day
And whan the woofull Fader deed it say
For woo his armes two he gan to bite
And seide allas fortune ⁊ weylaway
Thy fals whele . my woo al may I wite
¶ His children wende that it for hunger was
That he hise armes gnowe ⁊ nat for woo
And seiden Fader . do nat so allas
But rather ete the fleisshe vpon vs twoo
Oure fleisshe thow yafe . take oure fleisshe vs froo
And eete ynow / right thus they to hym seyde
And aftir that with ynne a day or twoo
They leyde hem in his lappe a doun ⁊ deyde
¶ Hym selfe despeyred eke for hunger starfe
Thus ended is / this myghty Erle of Pize
From heigh estaat fortune a way hym carfe
Of this tragedie it oughte ynough suffise
Who so wole here it in a lenger wyse
Redeth the grete Poet of Itaille
That hight Dant for he kan it all deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt . nat o worde wole he faile

l.hi: Here the knyght stynteth the Monke of his tale
Here the knyght stynteth the Monke of his tale

div.l: HO qd oure oste good sire nomore of this
That ye han seide is right ynow I wys
And more for litel heuynesse
Is right ynow to moche folke I gesse
I say for me it is a greet disease
Where as men han ben in greet welthe ⁊ ease
To here of hire sodeyn falle allas
And the contrarie is ioye ⁊ grete solace
As whan a man hath ben in poure astate
And clymbeth vp ⁊ wexeth fortunate
And there abideth in prosꝑperite
Soche thynge is gladsom as thynketh me
And of soche thynge were goodly for to telle
I se qd oure ooste by seint Poules belle
Ye sey right soth / this Monke he crieth loude
He spake how fortune couꝰered with a cloude
I note neuꝰer what ⁊ also of tregedie
Right now ye herde and parde no remedie
Yt is for to be waillen / ne compleyne
That þtat is doon / and also it is a peyne
As ye haue seide to here of heuynesse
Sir Monke nomore of this so god yow blesse
Youre tale anoieth al this cōmpanye
Soche thynge is nat worth a boter flye
For there in there is disporte ne game
Where fore sire Monke . O . daun Piers by youre name
I prey yow hertely telle vs somwhat ellys
For sikirly ne clynkynge of youre bellys
That on youre bridel hange . on euꝰery syde
By heuene kynge . that for vs alle deyde
I shulde er this . haue fallen doun for slepe
Al though the slowe / hadde neuꝰer ben so deepe
Thanne hadde youre tale / al be tolde in veyne
For certeynly as that these clerkis seyne
Where as a man may haue non audience
Nought helpeth it . to tellen his sentence
And wele I woot the substaunce is in me
Yf any thynge shall wele reported be
Sire sey somwhat of huntynge I yow preye
¶ Nay qd this Monke . I haue no luste to pleye
Now late a nother telle as I haue tolde
Than spake oure hoost . with rude speche ⁊ bolde
And seide vnto the Nonnes preest anoon
Com neer thow preest . come hider þu sir Iohn
Telle vs swiche thynge . as may oure hertes glade
Be blithe . thow þu ride vpon a Iade
What thow thyn hors . be bothe foule ⁊ lene
Yf he wole serue the . rekke nat a bene
Loke þtat thyn herte be merie euꝰer moo
Yis sir qd he . yis so mote I goo
But I be merie . I wole be blamed
And right a noon his tale he hath attamed
And thus he seide . vnto vs euꝰerychon
This swete preest this goodly man sir Iohn

hi.hi: Here bygynneth the Nonnes prestes tale

div.l: A Pore widowe somdele stape in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narwe a cotage
Bysyde a groue stondynge in a dale
This widwe of whiche I telle yow my tale
Syn thilke day that she was laste a wyfe
In pacience ladde a full sympul lyfe
For litel was hire catel / ⁊ here rente
By housbondrye / of whiche as god hire sente
Shee fonde hire selfe ⁊ eke hire doughtren twoo
Thre large sowes hadde she ⁊ nomoo
Thre kyne ⁊ eke a sheep that hight Malle
Full sooty was hire boure . ⁊ eke hire halle
In whiche she eete full many a sklender mele
Of poynaunt sawce . hire neded neuꝰer a dele
Noo deynte Morsel . passed thurgh hire throte
Hire diete was accordaunt to hire cote
Repleccion ne made hire neuꝰer syke
A tempre diete was al hire Phisike
And excercise / and hertes suffisaunce
The gowte lette hire no thynge for to daunce
Napoplexie . shent nat hire heed
No wyn ne dranke she neither white ne reed
Hire boord was serued moste with white ⁊ blakke
Melke ⁊ broun breed in whiche she foond no lakke
Seynd bacoun ⁊ somtyme an ey or tweye
For she was as it were a maner deye
A yerde she hadde enclosed al aboute
With stikkes . and a drie diche with oute
In whiche she hadde a Cokke heet Chauntecleere
In alle the londe . of crowyng nas his pere
His voys was Mirier than the myrye orgon
On Masse dayes / that in chirche goon
Wele sikerer was his crowyng in his logge
Thanne is a clokke . or any Abbey Orlogge
By nature he crewe eche assencioun
Of the equinoxial in thilke toun
For whan degrees xv . were ascended
Than crewe he / that it myght nat ben amended
His Combe was redder . than the fyn coralle
And batailled as it were a castel walle
His bile was blakke . and as þe Ieet it shoon
Lyke Asure were his legges . and his toon
His nailles whiter than þe lilie floure
And like the burned golde was his coloure
This gentil cok hadde in his gouꝰernaunce
Seuene hennes for to doon all his plesaunce
Whiche were his sustres . ⁊ hise ꝑperamours
And wonder like to hym as of colours
Of whiche the fairest hewed on hire throte
Was cleped faire Damesel Pertelote
Curteys she was discreet ⁊ debonaire

Now am I come vnto the wodes syde
Maugre youre heed / þe cok shal here abide
I wole hym ete I feith ⁊ that a noon
¶ The Foxe answered I feith it shall be doon
And as he spak that worde / al sodeynly
This Cokke brake from his mouthe delyuerly
And hye vpon a tree he flye a noon
And whan the Fox sey that he was goon
Allas qd he . o . Chaunteclere allas
I haue to yow qd he / y doon trespas
In as myche as I maked yow a ferde
Whan I yow hente ⁊ brought in to þe yerde
But sire I dede it . in no wicke entente
Come doun ⁊ I shalle telle yow what I mente
I shall sey sooth to yow / god helpe me so
¶ Nay thanne qd he I shrewe vs bothe two
And firste I shrewe my selfe booth blood ⁊ bones
If yu bygyle me / any ofter than ones
Thow shalte namore / thorugh thy flaterie
Do me so synge / ⁊ wynke wtith myn ye
For he that wynketh whan he sholde y see
Al wylfully god lete hym neuꝰer y thee
Nay qd the Foxe . but god yef hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaunce
That Iangleth whan he sholde holde his pees
Lo swiche it is for to be recchelees
And necligent ⁊ truste on flaterye
But ye that helden this tale a folye
As of a Foxe or of a Cok / or hen
Taketh the moralite good men
For seint Poule seith . that al that writen is
To oure doctryne . it is y write y wys
Taketh the fruyt . ⁊ late the chafe be stille
Now good god if that it be thy wille
As seith my lorde so make vs alle good men
And brynge vs to his blysse amen
¶ Sire Nonnes preest oure hoost seyde a none
Y blessed be thy breth ⁊ euꝰery stoone
This was a mery tale of Chaunteclere
But be my trouthe if þu were seculere
Thow woldeste bene a tredefoul a right
For if thow haue corage as þu haste myght
The were nede of hennes as I wene
Ye moo than . vij . tymes seventene
See whiche braunnes hath þs gentel preeste
So grete a nekke ⁊ so large a breeste
He loketh as a Sparhauke with his yen
Hym nedeth nat his colour for to dyen
With Brasile ne with Greyne of Portyngale /
Now sire faire falle yow for youre tale
And aftir he with full mery chere
Saide vnto a nother as ye shulle here

hi.hi:
Here is ended the Nonnes prestes tale
And folowith the ꝓprologe of the Maunciples tale

div.l: (base) And folowith the ꝓprologe of the Maunciples tale
(base) WOot ye nat where ther stante a litel toun

(base) And seide sires / what don is in þe Myre

(base) A theef myght hym . ful lightly robbe ⁊ bynde
(base) See how he nappeth . se how for cokkys bones
(base) That he wole falle / fro his hors atones
(base) Is that a Cook of london / with meschaunce

(base) For he shalle telle a tale be my feye

div.l: (base) I wole as nowe excuse the of thy tale

(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man . by thy fader kyn

(base) For were it wyn or olde mosty ale

div.l: (base) But yet Manciple in feith thow arte to nyce
(base) Thus openly reproue hym of his vice
(base) A nother day he wole ꝑperauenture
(base) Reclayme the ⁊ brynge þe to lure
(base) I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
(base) As for to pynchen / at thy rekenynges

(base) Telle on thy tale / Manciple I the prey

(base) Explicit ꝓprophemiūn

div.l: (base) Here bygynnyth the manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adown
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the moost lusty bachilere
(base) In alle this worlde . ⁊ eke the beste Archere
(base) He slowe Phyton the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge a gayn the sonne . vpon a day
(base) And many a nother / noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wrought . as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he cowde . on euꝰery mynstralcye
(base) And syngen / that it was a melodye
(base) To heren / of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kynge / of thebes Amphyoun
(base) That with hys syngyng walled that Cite
(base) Koude neuꝰer syngen / halfe so wele as he
(base) Ther to he was the semelyest man
(base) That is or was / sith that the worlde bygan
(base) What nedeth it his fetures to descryue
(base) For in this worlde was noon so faire on lyue
(base) He was ther with fulfilled of gentilesse
(base) Of honoure ⁊ of ꝑperfite worthynesse
(base) This Phebus that was floure of bachilrye
(base) As wele in fredom / as in cheualrye
(base) For his disporte in signe of victorie
(base) Of Phiton so as telleth vs the storie
(base) Was wonte to beren in his hande a bowe
(base) Now hadde this Phebz in his hows a crowe
(base) Whiche in a Cage he fostred many a day
(base) And taughte it speke . as men teche a Iay
(base) White was this crowe . as is a snowe whit swan
(base) And countre feted the speche of euꝰery man
(base) He coude whenne he sholde telle a tale
(base) Therwith / in al this worlde no nyghtyngale
(base) Ne koude by an hundred thousand dele
(base) Syngen so wonder muryly ⁊ wele
(base) Now hadde this Phebz in his hous a wyf
(base) Whiche that he loued more than his lyf
(base) And nyght ⁊ day dide euꝰer his diligence

div.l: (base) Hire for to plese . ⁊ doon hire reuꝰerence

(base) For hym were looth / byiaped for to be

(base) But al fornought for it availleth nought
(base) A good wife that is clene / in werke ⁊ thought
(base) Shulde nat ben kepte in noon a waite certayn
(base) And trewely / the labour is in veayn

(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues
(base) Thus writen / olde Clerkys in hire lyues

(base) Take any bridde . ⁊ put it in a cage

(base) Of alle deyntees that thow canste bythynke

(base) And euꝰery deynte that is in that hous

div.l: (base) And Appetite flemeth discrecion

(base) A man of litel reputacioun

Lo how that Iacob . as these Clerkes rede right
By good counseil / of his Moder Rebekke
Bonde the kydes skyn a boute his nekke
For whiche his Fadres benyson he wan /
¶ Lo Iudith as the storie eke telle kan right
By wys counseile . she goddes peple kepte
And slow hym Olofernus while he slepte /
Lo Abigail . by good counseile how she
Saued hire housbonde Nabal . whan that he
Sholde han ben slayn . ⁊ loke Ester also
By good counseille delyuꝰered oute of woo
The peple of god . ⁊ made hym Mardoche right
Of Assuer / enhaunsed for to be /
Ther is no thynge in gree suꝑperlatyfe
As seith Senek . a boue an humble wyfe /
Suffre thy wyfes tunge . as Caton bitte
She shal cōmmaunde ⁊ thow shalt suffren it
And yet she wole obeye of curtesye /right
A wife is keper of thyn housbondrye right
Wele may the seke man be waille ⁊ wepe
Ther as ther nys no wyfe the hous to kepe /
I warne the . if wysely thow wolte werche
Loue wele thy wyfe . as crist loued his cherche
If thow louest thy selfe . thow louest thy wyfe
Noman hateth his fleisshe but in his lyfe
He fostreth it . and therfore bidde I thee

l.hi: Cherisshe thy wyfe or thow shalt neuꝰer thee /

div.l: Housbonde ⁊ wyfe . what so men Iape or pleye
Of worldly folke holde the syker weye /right
They ben so knytte . ther may noon harm betyde
And namely vpon the wyues syde /
For whiche / this Ianuarie of whiche I tolde
Considered hath . Inwith his daies olde
The lusty lyfe . the vertuouse quiete
That is in mariage / hony swete
And for his frendes on a day he sente
To tellen hem theffecte of his entente
With face sadde . this tale he hath hem tolde
He seide frendes . I am hoore ⁊ olde
And almoste god wote on my pittes brynke
Vpon my soule sōmwhat moste I thynke
I haue my body folyly dispended
Blessed be god / that it shal be amended
For I wole certeyn a wedded man
And that a noon in al the haste I kan
Vnto som maide / faire ⁊ tendre of age
I pray yow shapeth for my mariage
Al sodenly for I wole nat abide
And I wole fonde / tespien on my syde
To whom I may be wedded hastily /
But for as moche . as ye beth mo than I
Ye shullen rather swiche a thyng espyen
Whanne ⁊ where me beste were to allien /
¶ But on thynge warne I yow . my frendes dere
I wole noon olde wyfe / han / in no manere
She shal nat passe .lx. yere certayn
Olde Fysshe / ⁊ yonge fleissh wold I haue ful fayn
Bet is qd he a pik than a pikerel
And bette than olde beef is the tendre veel
I wole no woman .xxx. yere of age
It is but benestrawe ⁊ greet forage
And eke these olde widewes / god it woot
They konne so moche crafte . on wades boot
So mochel broken harme whan hem leste
That with hem / shuld I neuꝰer leue in reste
For sondry scoles / maketh subtil Clerkis
Wōmmen of many scoles halfe a clerke is /
But certeynly . a yong thyng may men gye
Right as men may . warm wexe / wtith handes plie
Wherfore I sey yow / pleynly in a clause
I wole noon olde wyfe han / right for this cause
For if so were I hadde swiche meschaunce
That I in here . ne koude haue no plesaunce
Thanne sholde I lede my lyfe in a vowtrie
And streyght to the deuel . whan I dye /
Ne children sholde I noon vppon . hire geten
Yet were me leuer houndes hadde me eten
Than that myn heritage sholde falle
In straunge honde / and this I telle yow alle
I dote nat / . I wote the cause why
Men sholde wedde / ⁊ ferthermore wote I
Ther speketh many a man of mariage
That woot nomore of it . than wote my page
For whiche causes . man sholde take a wife /
If he ne may nat leue chaste hys lyfe
Take hym a wyfe with grete deuocion
By cause of leful procreacoūn
Of children / to honour of god a boue
And nat oonly for ꝑperamour ofr loue
And for they sholde leccherie eschue
And yelde hir dette whan that it is dewe
Or for that eche of hem / sholde helpen other
In myschief as a suster shal the brother
And lyue in chastite ful hollyly /
But sires by youre leue / that am nat I
For god be thanked / I dar make auant
I fele my lemes sterke / ⁊ suffisaunt
To doo al that a man bylongeth to
I woot my seluen beste what that I may do
Thow I be hore . I fare as dooth a tree
That blosmeth . er that fruyt y woxen be
And blosmy tree / nys neyther drie ne dede
I fele me now heer hoor / but on my hede /
Myn herte ⁊ al my lymes ben as grene
As laurer thourgh the yere / is for to sene
And syn that ye han herde / almyn entente
I pray yow to my wille / ye wole assente /
¶ Dyuers men . dyuersely hym tolde
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Som blamed it . som preised it certeyn /
But at laste shortely for to seyn
As alday falleth altercacion
Bitwix frendis / ⁊ disputison
Ther fel a stryfe be twix his brethern too
Of whiche that oon was cleped placebo
Iustinus soothly called was that other
Placebo seyde / o Ianuarie brother
Ful litel nede / hadde ye my lord so dere
Counseile to axe . of any that is here
But that ye ben so ful of sapience
That yow ne liketh / for youre hye prudence
To weyuen fro the word of Salomon
This worde seide he / vnto vs euꝰerychon
Wirke al thynge be counseile / thus seide he
And than shalt thow . nat repente the /
But thow that Salomon / spak swiche a word
Myn owene dere brother . ⁊ my lorde
So wisly god my soule brynge at reste
I holde youre owen counseile is the beste
For brother myne of me take this motyf
I haue now ben a court man al my lyf
And god it woot / thogh I vnworthi be
I haue stonden in ful degree
A bouten lordes of ful greet estate
Yet hadde I neuꝰere with noon of hem debate
I neuꝰere hem contraried trewely
I woot wele that my lorde kan more than I
What that he seith . I holde it ferme ⁊ stable
I sey the same / or elles thynge semblable
A ful greet fole / is any counseillour
That serueth any lorde of heigh honour
That dare presume or elles thenke it
That his counseile shold passe his lordes wit
Nay lordes ben no fooles / by my fay
Ye han youre seluen / heer to day
So heigh sentence so holyly ⁊ wele
That I consente ⁊ conferme euꝰerydel
Youre wordes alle . and youre opynyoun
By god ther nys no man . in al this toun
Ne in Itaile . couthe bette han I sayde /
Crist halt hym of this counseil . ful wele apayd
And trewely it is an heigh corage
Of any man / that stapen is in age
To take a yonge wyfe / by my fader kyn
Youre herte hongeth on a Ioly pyn
Doth now in this matere right as yow lest
For finally I holde it for the best /
¶ Iustinus that ay stille sate and herde /
Right in this wise he to Placebo answerde /
Now brother myn be pacient I preye
Syn ye han seide / ⁊ herkeneth what I seye
Senek a monges other wordes wise left
Seith that a man ought hym riȝt wele auyse
To whom he yeueth his londe or his catele
And syn I oughte . auysen me right wele
To whom I yeue my good a way fro me
Wele moche more . I ought auysen me
To whom I yeue my body / for alwey
I warne yow wele it is no childes pley
To take a wyfe with outen auysement
Men moste enquere this is myn assente
Wher she be wys ⁊ sobre . or dronkelewe
Or proude / or elles other weyes a shrewe
A chidestere . or wastour of thi good
Or riche or pore . or mannyssh wood
Al be it so / that no man fynden shal
Noon in this world / that trotteth hool in al
Ne man ne beste . swiche as men coude deuyse /
But natheles . it ought I now suffise
With any wyfe / if so were that she hadde
Moo good thewes / than hire vices badde
And alle this axeth leyser tenquere /
For god it woot / I haue wepte many a tere
Ful piriuely syn that I hadde a wyfe
Preise who so wole a wedded mann9 lyfe
Certeyn I fynde in it . but coste ⁊ care
And obꝸseruaunces . of alle blisses bare
And yet god woot . my neighebors aboute
And namely of wymen many a route
Seyn that I haue the most stedefast wyf
And eke the mekest oon that bereth lyf
Bote I woot beste / where wryngeth me my shoo
Ye mowe for me right as yow liketh doo
Auyseth yow . ye ben a man of age
How that ye entren into mariage
And namely with a yonge wyfe ⁊ a fair
By hym that made water erthe ⁊ ayr
The yongest man that is in al this route
Is besy I now to bryngen it a boute
To han his wyfe allone tristeth me
Ye shulle nat pleasen hire fully yeris thre
This to seyn to doon hire ful plesaunce
A wife axeth ful many an obꝸseruaunce
I prey yow that ye be nat yuel apaid /
Wele qd this Ianuarie / and hastow y sayd ;
Strawe for thy Senek and for thy ꝓprouerbes
I counte nat a panyer ful of herbes
Of scole termes / wiser men than thow
As thow haste herde assentedyn right now
To my pupos / Placebo what say ye
I sey it is a cursed man / qd he
That letteth Matrymoigne sikerly
And with that worde . they risen sodeynly
And ben assented fully that he sholde
Be wedded whan hym luste ⁊ where he wolde
¶ Heigh fantasye / and curious besynesse
Fro day to day / gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuarie / a boute his mariage
Many faire shap . ⁊ many a faire visage
Ther passeth thurgh his herte nyght be nyght
As who so toke a Myrrour polisshed bright
And sette it in a comune Market place
Than shulde he see ful many a figure pace
By his myrrour . and in the same wyse
Gan Ianuarie / in with his thoght deuyse
Of Maidens whiche that dwelten hym bysyde right
He wiste nat where that he myght abyde
For if that oon haue beaute in hire face
Another stant so in the peples grace
For hir sadnesse ⁊ hir benygnyte
That of the peple . grettest voys hath she
And sōmme were riche . ⁊ hadden badde name
But natheles bitwix ernest ⁊ game
He atte laste / apoynted hym oon
And lete alle other from his herte goon
And chees hire of his owne auctorite
For loue is blynde alday ⁊ may nat see /
And whan that he was in his bedde y brought
He purtreide in his herte and in his thought
Hire freisshe beaute . and hire age tendre
Hire Middel smal . here armes longe ⁊ sclendre
Hire wise gouꝰernaunce . hire gentilesse
Hire womanly beryng ⁊ hir sadnesse
And whan that he on hire . was condescended
Hym thought his choys myght noght ben amended /
For whan that he hym selfe . concluded hadde
Hym thought eche other mannys witte so badde
That impossible / it were to replie
Agayn his choys . this was his fantasye /
His frendes sente he too / at his instaunce
And praied hym to doon hym that plesaunce
That hastely . they wolden to hym come
He wolde abregge her labour alle ⁊ some
Nedeth nomore for hym to goo ne ride
He was apoynted ther he wolde abyde
¶ Placebo cam ⁊ eke his frendes sone
And Alderfirst he bade hem alle a bone
That noon of hem / non argumentz make
A gayn the purpos . whiche that he hath take
Whiche purpos was plesaunt to god seyde he
And verrey ground of his ꝓprosꝑperite /
He seyde ther was a maide in the toun
Whiche of beaute hadde grete renoun
Al were it so . she were of smal degre
Suffiseth hym her youthe ⁊ hire beaute
Whiche maide he seide / he wolde han to his wife
To lede in ese ⁊ holynesse his lyfe
And thanked god that he myght han hir al
That no wight his blisse parten shal
And preied hem to labour in this nede
And shapen that he faile nat to spede
For thanne he seyde . his spirit was at ese
Than is qd he . nothyng may me displese
Saue o thynge priketh in my conscience
The whiche I wole reherce in youre pꝰersence
I haue qd he herde seyde . ful yore a goo
Ther may no man han ꝑperfit blisses twoo
This is to seye . in erthe ⁊ eke in heuene
For though he kepe hym fro the synnes seuene
And eke from euꝰery braunche of thilke tree
Yet is there so ꝑperfite felicite
And so grete eese ⁊ luste in mariage
That euꝰer I am a gaste now in myn / age
That I shal lede now / so mury a lyfe
So delicate with oute woo or stryfe
That I shal han my / heuene in erthe here
For sith that verrey heuene is bought so dere
With tribulacoūn ⁊ grete penaunce
How sholde I thanne leuen in in swiche plesaunce
As alle wedded men . do with hire wyues
Come to the blysse . ther criste eterne on lyue is
This is my drede . ⁊ ye my bretheren twey
Assoilleth me this question I prey /
Iustinus whiche that hated his folie
Answerde a noon right in his Iaperye
And for he wolde his longe tale a bregge
He wolde non auctorite allegge
But seide sire . so ther be non obstacle
Other than this / god of his hye myracle
And of his mercy may so for yow wirche
That er ye han . youre right of holy chirche
Ye may repente of wedded mann9 lyfe
In whiche ye seyn / ther nys no woo ne stryfe
And elles god forbede but he sente
A wedded man / hym grace to repente
Wele ofte rather . than a sengle man
And therfore sire the beste rede I kan
Dispeire yow noght but haue in youre memorie
ꝐPeraunter she may be youre purgatorie
She may be goddys mene . and goddis whippe
Than shal youre soule vp to heuene skippe
Swifter than doth an arwe . oute of a bowe
I hope to god . her after shul ye knowe
That ther nys non so grete felicite
In mariage ne neuꝰer mo shal be
That yow shal lette . of youre sauacion
So that ye vse as skile is ⁊ reson
The lustes of youre wife attemprely
And that ye plese hir nat to amorously
And that ye kepe yow eke from other synne
My tale is doon for my witte is thynne
Beth nat agaste her of my brother dere
But late vs waden oute of this matere
The wyfe of Bathe . yf ye han vndirstonde
Of mariage whiche we han on honde
Declared hath ful wele in litel space /
Fareth now wele god haue yow in his grace /
And with this worde . Iustyn ⁊ his brother
Han take hir leue . ⁊ eche of hem of other /
For whan they sawe . that it most nedes be
They wroughten so / be sly ⁊ wys trete
That she this maiden . whiche that Mayus hight
As hastely . as euꝰer that she myght
Shal wedded be vnto this Ianuarie /
I trowe it were so longe yow to tarie
Yf I yow tolde of euꝰery scripte ⁊ bonde
By whiche that she was feffed in his honde
Or for to herknen . of hire riche array
But finally . y comen is that day
That to the chirche / bothe be they wente
For to resceyue / the holy sacrament
Forth cometh the preest . with stole a boute his nekke
And bade hir bylyke . Sarra . ⁊ Rebekke
In wisdom ⁊ in trouth of mariage
And seide his orisons . as is vsage
And crowched hem . ⁊ bade god sholde hem blesse
And made al siker y nowe . with holynesse
Thus ben they wedded with solempnite
And at the feste sitteth he ⁊ she
With other worthy folke vpon the deys
Al ful of Ioye ⁊ blisse is the paleys
And ful of Instrumentz ⁊ of vitaille
The moste deynteuous of alle Itaille
Byforn hem stood swiche instrumentz of swiche soun
That Orpheus . nof Thebes Amphyon
Ne maden neuꝰer swiche a melodie
At euꝰery cours than cam loud mynstralcie
That neuꝰer trumped Ioab for to here
Ne he Therdomas yet halfe so clere
At Thebes whan the Cite was in doute
Bachus the wyn hem shynketh al aboute
And venus laugheth vpon euꝰery wight
For Ianuarie was bicome her knyght
And wolde bothe assaie his corage
In liberte ⁊ eke in mariage
And with hire firbrond in hir hand a boute
Daunceth byforn the bride / and alle þe route
And certeynly I dar right wele sey this
Imeneus that god of weddyng is
Say neuꝰer his lyfe . so mury a wedded man /
Holde thow thi pees . thow Poet Marcian
That writest vs . that ilke weddynge murye
Of hire Philologie . and hym Mercurie
And of the songes that the muses songe /
To smal is bothe thy penne . ⁊ eke thy tonge
For to descryuen of this mariage
Whan tendre youthe . hath wedded stoupyng age
Ther is swiche merthe . that it may nat be writen
Assaieth it youre selfe / than may ye witen
If that I lye or noon in this matere /
Mayus that sitte . with so benygne a chere
Hir to byholde . it semed fairye
Quene . Ester loked neuꝰer with swiche an ye
On Assuer so meke a look hath she /
I may yow nat deuyse al hir beaute /
But thus moche of hire beaute telle I may /
That she was like the bright morwe of May
Fulfilled of alle beaute ⁊ plesaunce /
This Ianuarie is rauysshed in a traunce /
At euꝰery tyme he loked on hire face
But in his herte he gan hir to manace
That he that nyght in armes wolde hir streyne
Harder than euꝰer Parys dide Eleyne /
But natheles / yet hadde he grete pite /
That thilke nyght offenden hire moste he /
And thoughte allas / o tendre creature
Now wold god / ye myght wele endure
Al my corage . it is so sharpe ⁊ kene /
I am a gaste . ye shul nat it sustene /
But god forbede I dede al my myght
Now wolde god . that it were waxen nyght
And that the nyght wole lasten euꝰer mo /
I wolde that al this peple were a go
And finally he doth alle his labour
As he beste myght / sauyng his honour
To haste hem fro the mete in sotil wise /
The tyme kam that reson was to rise /
And aftir that men daunce ⁊ drynke faste
And spices al a boute the hous they caste
And ful of Ioye ⁊ blisse is euꝰery man /
Al but a Squier hight Damyan
Whiche karfe byfore the knyght many a day /
He was so rauysshed on that lady May
That for the verrey peyne / he was nyz wood
Almoste he swelte . and swowned as he stood /
So sore hath venus . hurte hym with hir brond
As that she bare it / daunsynge in hire hond
And to his bedde he went hym hastyly /
Nomore of hym / at this tyme speke I /
But there I lete hym wepe ynow and pleyne
Til freisshe May . wol rewen on his peyne
O perilous fire . that in the bedstrawe bredeth /
O famulier foe that his seruise bedith
O ꝸseruant traitour . false homly hewe
Lyke to the Neddre in bosom / sly vntrewe
God shilde vs alle . from youre acqueintaunce /
O Ianuarie . dronken in plesaunce
In Mariage se how thy Damyan
Thyn owne Squyer . and thy born man
Entendeth for to do the vylenye /
God graunt the thy homly foo espie

l.hi: For in this world . nys worse pestilence

div.l: Than homly foo / alday in thy pꝰersence /
ꝐPerfourmed hath the sonne . this Ark diurne
No lenger may the body of hym soiourne
On thorisonte / as in that / latitude
Right with his mantel . that is derke ⁊ rude
Gan ouꝰer sprede / themysperie aboute /
For whiche deꝑperted is . this lusty route
Fro Ianuarie . with thanke on euꝰery syde
Hoom to hire houses / lustely they ryde
Where as they doon hem thynges as hem lyste
And whan they sey her tyme go to reste /
Sone aftir that . this hasty Ianuarie
Wole go to bedde he wole no lenger tarie
He drynketh ypocras . clarre ⁊ vernage
Of spices hote . tencrescen his corage
And many a letuarie hadde he ful fyn
Swiche as the Cursed Monke . Daun Constantyn
Hath writen in his book de coitu
To eten hem alle . he nas no thynge eschewe
And to hise piriue frendes . thus seide he
For goddis loue as sone as it may be
Late voiden al this hous . in curteys wise /
And they han doon . right as he wole deuyse /
Men drynken / and the trauers drawe anoon
The bride was brought a bedde . as stille as stoon
And whan the bedde was with the preest y blessed
Oute of the chaumbre hath euꝰery wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath / faste in armes take
His freisshe May / his paradys / his make
He lulleth hire . he kysseth hire ful ofte
With thilke bristles / of his berde vnsofte
Lyke to the skyn of houndfisshe sharpe as brere
For he was shaue al newe . in his manere
He rubbeth hire . a boute hire tendre face
And seide thus . Allas / I mote trespace
To yow my spouse / and yow gretly offende
Er tyme come . that I wole / doun descende
But natheles considereth this qd he
Ther nys no werkman . (what so euꝰer he be)
That may both werke wele ⁊ hastely
This wole be do at leyser ꝑperfitly .
It is no fors how longe that we pleye
In trewe wedlok coupled be we tweye
And blissed be the yokke that we ben Inne
For in actes . we mow do no synne
A man may do no synne with his wyfe
Ne hurte hym seluen with his owen knyfe
For we haue leue for to pleye as by the lawe /
Thus lauboreth . til that the day gan dawe
And thanne he taketh a soppe in fyn clarre
And vpright in his bedde than sitteth he
And aftir that he songe ful loude ⁊ clere
And kyste his wyfe . ⁊ made wantown chere
He was al Coltisshe ful of ragerye
And ful of Iargoūn . as a flekked pye /
The slak skyn a boute his nekke shaketh
While that he songe . so chaunteth he ⁊ craketh /
But god woot what that may thought in hire herte
Whan she hym sawe vp sittynge in his sherte
In his nyght cappe . and with his nekke lene
She preiseth nat his pleiyng worth a bene /
Than seide he thus my reste wole I take
Now day is come I may no lenger wake
And doun he leide his heed / ⁊ sleep / til prime
And aftirward whan he sawe his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie / but freisshe May
Helde hir chambre vnto the ferthe day
As vsage is of wyues . for the beste
For euꝰery labour somtyme moot haue reste
Or elles / longe may he nat endure /
This is to seyn / no lyues creature
Be it of fisshe / or brid / or beest / or man /
¶ Now wole I speke of woful Damyan
That langwissheth for loue . as ye shul here /
Therfore I speke to hym in this manere
I sey / o sely Damyan allas
Answere to my demaunde as in this cas
How shaltow to thy lady freisshe May
Telle thy wo . she wole alwey sey nay /
Eke if thow speke / she wol thy woo be wreye
God be thyn helpe I kan no bettre seye /
This sike Damyan . in venus fire
So brenneth / that he dieth for desire /
For whiche / put his lyfe in aventure
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But piriuely a penner gan he borwe
And in a lettre wroot he al his sorwe
In manꝰer of a compleynt or a lay
Vnto his faire freisshe lady May
And in a purs of selke henge on his sherte
He hath it putte / ⁊ leyde it at his herte
¶ The mone that at noon was thilke day
Þat Ianuarie hath wedded freissh May
In two of Taure / was in to Cancre gliden
So longe hath Maius in hire chambre abiden
As custume is / vnto this nobles alle /
A bride / shal nat eten in the halle
Til daies foure . or thre daies . atte leeste
I passed ben / than late hire goo to feste /
The fourth day complete / from noon to noon
Whan that the heigh masse was y doon
In halle sitte this Ianuarie ⁊ May
As freissh as is the bright someris day
And so byfel how that this good man
Remembred hym . vpon thys Damyan
And seide seynt marie how may it be
That Damyan entendeth nat to me
Is he ay sike . or how may this bitide ;
His squyers whiche that stoden ther bysyde

div.l: By that the yeman hadde this tale al ended
The sonne fro the South lyne was descended
So lowe that it nas nat to my sight
Degrees . 29 . as of hyght
Foure of the Clokke it was tho as I gesse
For xj . foot . and litel more or lesse
My shadewe was / at thilke tyme as there
Of swiche feet as my lengthe partid were
In . 6 . feet equal of ꝓproporcioun
Ther with the Mones exaltacioun
I mene libra alwey gan ascende
As we were entryng at a thropes ende
¶ For whiche oure hoost . as he was wont to gye
As in this caas / oure ioly companye
Seyde in thys wyse / lordynges euerichon
Now lakketh vs no tales moo than oon
Fulfylde is my sentence / ⁊ my decree
I trowe that we han herde of eche degree
Almoost fulfilde is al myn ordynaunce
I prey to god . so yeue hym right good chaunce
That telle vs shalle . a tale lustely
Sire preest qd he art thow a vicary
Oo erte a persoun . sey soth by thy fey
So what thow be . ne breke thow oure pley
For euꝰery man saue thow . hath toold his tale
Vnbokele / ⁊ shewe vs what is in thy male
For trewely me thynketh by thy chere
Thow sholdest knytte vp wele a grete matere
Telle vs a fable a noon for Cokkys bones
¶ This ꝑperson answerde at at ones
Thow geest fable noon y tolde for me
For Poule that writeth vnto Thymothe
Repreueth hem that weyuen sothfastnesse
And tellen fables . and siche wrecchidnesse
Why sholde I . sowen draffe out of my fest
Whan that I may sowen whete yf that me lest
For whiche I sey / that if yow lyste to here
Moralite ⁊ vertuous matere
And thanne that ye wole yeue me Audience
I wole fulfayn . at cristes reuꝰerence
Do yow plesaunce leueful as I kan
But trusteth wele . I am a sowthren man
I kan . nat geste rom / ram / ruf / by lettre
Ne god woot ryme holde I but litel bettre
And therfore yf yow lyste / I wole nat glose
I wole yow telle a mery tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste . ⁊ make an ende
And Ihu for his grace witte me sende
To shewe yow the wey in this viage
Of thilke ꝑperfit glorious pilgrymage
That hight Ierlm celestialle
And yf ye vouche saufe anoon I shalle
By gynne vpon my tale for . whiche I prey
Telle youre auys . I kan no better sey
But natheles / this meditacioun
I putte it ay vndir correctioun
Of Clerkys for I am nat textuel
I take but the sentence trusteth wel
Therfore I make ꝓprotestacioun
That I wole stonde to correccioun
¶ Vpon thys worde . we han assented sone
For as it semed it was for to done
To enden in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym space ⁊ audience
And bede oure hooste he sholde to hym seye
That alle we / to telle his tale hym preye
¶ Oure hoost hadde the wordes . for vs alle
Sire preest qd he / now faire yow byfalle
Sey what yow lyste . and we wole gladly here
And with that worde . he seide in this manere
Telleth qd he youre meditacioun
But hasteth yow the sonne wole a doun
Beeth fructious and that in litel space
And to do wele . god send yow his grace
Explicit ꝒProhemium
